  20. I've been using the traditional Norelco razors for decades and have been satisfied. They've all lasted a long time and done a good job.<br /><br />This new 3D razor is much more comfortable and does the job significantly faster than the older models. It's also a wet-dry razor that you can use in the shower or with shaving cream, although I haven't tried either of those options yet.<br /><br />I bought the least expensive 3D model since the only difference with the more expensive models are more sophisticated power indicators. The three indicator lights with the last one turning red when it's time to recharge are quite sufficient. Go with the model 40 and save your money.<br /><br />Update October 7, 2012:<br /><br />I've had the razor for coming up on two years now and it's still working perfectly. Battery charges and holds charge, no water damage even though I use it frequently in the shower. Original blade unit is still sharp.
  21. After using a Remington Electric razor for about 6 months I was ready to go back to blade razors. I tried a Norelco Spectra and loved it.   25. I've used Norelco shavers for the past 35 years. My last last one had been rebuilt about twenty years ago, and later had the cutting head replaced as well as the battery. Even though it was still working relatively well, I wanted a little better shave for my aging face. After looking at the makes and models of shavers on display in the stores I shop at, I cruised the internet and did more research on shavers. I settled on the Philips Norelco 1250x/40 SensoTouch 3d shaver because the descriptions of what it could do design wise was just what I was looking for. I didn't need the additional bells and whistles of the even higher models of Norelco. A month later, I (and my wife) am extremely happy with my purchase. It has surpassed my expectations of how it would perform. The trimmer is also better designed and more effective on the side burns as well as other stay hairs on the ears, etc. Thanks to Norelco for the design and rebate, and to Amazon.com for the great price opportunity. This has been another happy purchase through Amazon.com. And to think, I used to think that they just sold books and music type stuff!!!!! (Let's see.... I've purchased speaker systems, cordless drills, ..................)
  26. This is the base model of the Senso Touch line with out all of the bells and whistles but the performance is top of the line. I have been using electric razors for 15 years and this gives, without a doubt, the best shave ever. I use it in the shower with a wet soapy face and have eliminated almost all irritation with the closest shave I have ever had, blade or electric. Two thumbs up!
  27. Close shaves wet or dry. Easy to clean. Sleek design making it easy to hold and maneuver. Overall great shaver...best one I've owned in years.

  31. I'm a college student living on a budget and this was a lot bigger of a purchase than any other typical razors I've bought! The Gillete just wasn't giving me a comfortable shave and I couldn't bare shaving every day for such a so so shave (it was really hard every time to get the curves around my chin). After putting up with it forever I saw this on Woot. I didn't give it much thought at first because it was so expensive but then it was nagging me so I started looking at reviews. I needed it to be a close shave, with no hair to feel if I ran my fingers across my face. I also needed it to be a comfortable shave, and be able to shave at least once a day and it not be painful. I'm that person that reads a ton of reviews before I buy something like this, and they were all absolutely right. I LOVE this razor and I wouldn't give it up for 10 years worth of free power glides or something. Smooth shave, and very comfortable. My brother was even astounded by the results I told him about, he commented he didn't know an electric razor could cut so close! And of course the girlfriend approved, so it was definitely a great purchase, no buyers remorse possible. A couple things about the actual features...Pretty easy to clean, though the manual is somewhat confusing (yeah, I'm one of those that read manuals too). Battery life is pretty sweet, I've shaved almost once per day since I got it (a month ago) and I just now had to recharge it. It does get a little hot towards the end of your shave which can make things take longer and not feel as nice as a cool razor, but it's not uncomfortable at all. Overall, an amazingly close and comfortable shave, and worth every penny. UPDATE (Nov 8 '11) - It was May 3 when I wrote this review, and nothing has changed. I still love it, still get great battery life out of it: I could count the number of times I've charged it probably with one hand. Carrying case is great for travel. Still gives a great shave, I've gotten a little lazy and at times if I don't go over my chin enough it'll miss the stubble. I'll say now that it's not going to shave everything off, especially with one pass. I shave and spend a few minutes, maybe 3 or 4, going over my cheeks, chin, mustache and neck. Neck can be tough and never really gets as close a shave as anywhere else, but that's kinda a priority issue. Gets a pretty great shave on the cheeks and mustache, except for right at the jaw line, it takes more effort and often there is more stubble there, but again I don't mind the little left behind. The chin is the toughest part to get. I end up just kinda pulling my skin (around the jaw line and chin) up and shaving it on a flatter surface to get it. Girlfriend is still happy, so I'm happy! I also have blonde hair, so I suppose I can't see any stubble left behind really; this might be different for a darker haired person. Still a great buy, I know I'll be getting a replacement head for it come ~April of next year!

  50. I have been using Norelco wet shavers for a good 10 years; the last one I bought and am still using is the model HS8420 (probably now obsolete) which gives me a reasonably good shave for an electric razor. I was hoping that the 3D Senso Touch model, at twice the price of the HS8420, would give at least as good a shave and hopefully superior shave. Imagine my disappointment when I discovered that the newer and higher priced 3D gives me a totally inferior shave even when using the Norelco shaver lubricant!<br /><br />It may be that the design of the 3D model, in order to allow for both dry and wet shaving, is necessarily not optimized for wet shaving. I have a tough beard and need all of the help I can get with an electric razor to minimize skin irritation. The older, 2D type, appears to do the job reasonably well, especially when I use the Norelco shaver lubricant frequently.<br /><br />The Norelco 3D Sens Touch may be good for other beards, not certainly not for mine!<br /><br />Update: The Norelco model HS8420 is still available on Amazon for $50, a real bargain for those who prefer wet shaves. This model is neither 2D nor 3D, as I understand it now. I believe both the 2D and 3D are sold to be used either wet or dry. This model HS8420 costs about only twice the price of its replaceable head. this head needs to be replaced, in my opinion, about once every six months, or possibly up to a year, depending upon the user's beard and how the shaver has been used.
  51. I love the process of shaving with a real razor because it's relaxing and there's a technique involved, but I hate doing it frequently because it takes time and it's somewhat messy. I actually shave very little, since my work doesn't require it. Now that I have the SensoTouch 3D, my coworkers are going to be shocked at how often I come in clean shaven. Simply put, this is the best electric shaver I've ever owned! It's quiet, fast, and cuts extremely close. I can't describe how impressive it is to have an electric razor that doesn't sound like a weed whacker. This guy sounds like a cell phone vibrating, very little noise at all. It's like getting a shave and a mini facial massage at the time. I think it took less than 5 minutes for me to dry shave the first time, after charging the unit overnight. It was quick and painless. The hair on my neck grows in a strange pattern and typically large amounts of hair get missed, if I use anything other than an actual razor. The SensoTouch 3D got most of the hair all the other electric shaver usually miss. I did have to go over the area a few times and that did cause a little irritation after the fact, but I think that's typical for using any new shaver for the first time. Clean up is a awesome. The hair gets collected into the unit while you use it, so very little if any hair lands in the sink (big points on the \\"Wife Score\\" chart). Then when you need too, you simply pop open the shaving heads and rinse this bad boy under the water. It couldn't be easier or more efficient. Plus, the ability to both dry and wet shave is great feature. I can't recommend this enough!!
  52. (Husband reviewing) Well, I was pretty impressed. I was very hesitant to try another electric razor, because they usually caused a lot of irritation to my skin. However, this was a good exception to the rule. It felt very smooth to the touch, and it was very soothing. As promised, the razor did adjust to my face, and was able to get out the hairs much better than I've had with electric razors in the past. With each time that I have used this razor, the cuts have been consistent and still just as smooth. Cleaning is easy as well. All you have to do is lift the head and the hairs are easy to retrieve. I also don't have to worry about running the battery. It looks like it has a pretty long life, but the charger works just as easily. Is it worth the $200? Well, in this economy, maybe you'd stick with the manual, because I'll admit the price is pretty steep. I do believe, however, that it does delivers what it promises, so I have to give it the highest rating.

  62. I've used Norelcos for many years. Typically when you buy a newer model (particularly at this price), you expect an improvement from older and lower priced units. Here's some highlights of how this compares to older units such as the Speed-XL line (which you can still find). Neck Shaving: With this razor, I have to go over the upper neck under the chin NUMEROUS times to even attempt to get a close shave. On the Speed-XL, the lip around the edge of the head housing seems to better setup the hairs for shaving as you move the razor across your skin. Senso= 1.5, Speed= 4. Trimmer: The placement of the trimmer on this razor means you can't see what you are trimming unless you pull the shaving head assembly off the razor. On the Speed-XL, flip the trimmer up, trim what you want and flip it down. If you are like me in that you make several trim touchups as you go over your face, the Senso is not the product for you. Also brings up reliability concerns for how many times the head assembly coupling can be pulled apart and reinserted without wearing out. The Speed-XL also has a wider cutting head making straight line trimming easier. Senso= 2, Speed= 5. Cleaning: With this razor, you must individually pop open each of the three heads. If you tap the razor against the faucet to shake it out, generally one or two of heads will swing closed meaning they don't get fully emptied. Being able to wash them out with water is good, but it requires HOT water. Don't want to think about how much energy is wasted by running the hot water faucet until you actually get to having hot water come out. Speed-XL, single button to release heads making it easy to tap them and shake out the shavings. Senso= 1.5, Speed= 4. Size shape and balance: Generally OK for both. However after having used a razor like the Speed-XL, the Senso seems excessively long and narrow (it's like trying to shave with a stick) while the Speed fits my hand better and is easier to maneuver. Senso= 3,Speed= 4. Overall, not worth the approximatly $70 more for the SensoTouch 3D unit. If sleek styling is your top priority, go for it. If practicality and shaving are your top priorities, try another razor.
  63. This is my first electric razor and till now i have used the Gillette Mach series. I bought this razor after a lot of research to understand the following 1. Which is better: rotary or foil 2. Should i buy a low cost product as trial or go for the best option 3. Will it completely replace my manual razor 4. Is the quality of shave equal to a careful manual shave You know the answer to the first 2 questions, and this is what i found 1. Rotary seems like a good choice, though using the round method to shave is much more difficult than I thought. Since I never bought a foil shaver, i still dont know which is bettwe, but sometimes I think the straight movement against the grain would be better and far quicker 2. I didnt want to reject the electric shavers on a poor model so decided to buy the best 3. The shaving takes time, more than a manual shave. You need to ensure carefully that you capture all the hair as just going over that area does not guarantee the same. So you need to constantly peer at the mirror to ensure that Secondly, its far less effective if you want to shave in the evening and then again in the morning 4. Overall, the quality of the shave is acceptable, since I wasnt too particular with my manual shave also on a daily basis. However, if its an important occasion, you probably want to dig out the manual blades However its great for traveling especially due to the liquid restrictions on flights (i only dry shave) Should you buy it? Yes. But remember if its an important occasion you may be better off using the manual blades

  66. With increasing frequency, these electric shaver companies release a new product, coming up with increasingly enticing words that turn out to be more hype than substance. But, we read these \\"words of hope\\" and gamble the money, only to be let down, just like I was with this shaver. I am sure you have read the sales pitch: \\"Sensotouch 3D.\\" \\"Combining gyroflex 3d, ultratrack heads and skinglide....\\" My gosh, I read \\"skinglide\\" and start to believe there can be no skin irritation with a shaver that has \\"skinglide.\\" They wrote this shaver has holes to catch the shortest stubble. Well, perhaps those holes are blocked since my shaver left so much stubble, and so much longer hair for that matter that I would give this shaver a total fail when keeping in context all that crap they wrote to sell this. I realize they will exaggerate to sell shavers, but this level of exaggeration is unacceptable. There is absolutely nothing extra special about this shaver. This shaver does exactly what every other shaver before it does. And not as good, in my opinion. So much hair is left on my face, I would only use this if I wanted the short stubble look. And yes, even with shave gel I still felt skin irritation. Lots of irritation. Please know that while Amazon only began selling it today, the shaver has been available from other sources since mid August. I have tried to stay with this shaver hoping things would improve, but they have not.

  68. I have always used regular razors and never had used an electric shaver until now. For those concerned about the price well, you get what you pay for, as soon as you see it and feel it you will understand this unit's price range. As a first time user I had to go through several shaves to adjust to the electric shaver and there was minor irritation on the first days. I can confirm by experience this is no longer an issue (a note is included asking you to give it at least 21 days of usage to get used to)<br /><br />Having as a reference the electric shaver of my grandfather and my dad, I was impressed by how little noise this unit makes, it is really quiet. The shave feels very smooth and close, maybe not as close as a razor but way more convenient if you shave on a daily basis. It is very compact and easy to clean. As a traveler, this is definitely more convenient (hotels normally have those cheap razors that do nothing but leave you with a red face, so I normally end up buying new ones on my trips)<br /><br />The charging times are fast and the rechargeable battery has lasted for almost two weeks now without having been recharged (used on a daily basis) which I think is great.<br /><br />Bottom-line, while cheaper units may do what you would consider the same job, the quality of the unit, the features and the convenience it offers would be reason enough to consider this electric shaver over others. In the end, you get what you pay for!

So yes, it shaves well, but I would never buy another one - who needs that much of a downside at that price.

  84. I stayed away from electric shavers for years after a terrible experience when I was younger- irritation, rashes, discomfort, etc. My new Norelco has given me nothig but close, comfortable shaves, wet or dry. I recommend it highly.
  85. Owned sever Norelcos in the past, they were all good, but when the last one I had started to die, I thought, for some reason, to try out a Braun. I picked the mid-range model, the 500. Awful shave. Took 3 times longer and did a worse job than any Norelco I'd owned. So now it's back to the Norelco line, and I couldn't be happier. I haven't had a shave this close and smooth since I used to shave with a razor back in the stone ages. This shaver is very powerful, and quick -- took about 2.5 minutes to get a perfect shave, and that's even around the edges of my beard. The charging station and remaining power readout are outstanding. The only downside is the included \\"trimmer\\" isn't the greatest, but I have a beard/trim razor for that functionality anyway, so that doesn't affect me. Would DEFINITELY recommend this razor to others.

  88. Good price compared to Australian Retail prices, great delivery time from amazon - only took a week for it to be delivered to Australia. Although, Amazon didnt assist in the price matching with another seller at the same time I bought this.. Not impressed Now, I have a 4yr old cheap $70 Philips shaver with the same cutting outcome and all the hair stays inside the shaver head. With this 3d norelco shaver, the hair falls out and messes up your shirt and you need to clean the shaver every time you use it or even more hair falls out. Beyond ridiculous. I can only imagine what would happen if you add water to your shaving rotuine - a mix of water and hair on your shirt... nice.
  89. Very close shave. Cleans easy. charge lasts very long. Ate me up the first couple uses, but I think that was my fault for push to hard. Great buy.
  90. First let me say this shaver is pretty amazing. I have tried many electric shavers in the past and like most, have given up on them as they are either too rough on my face or they just don't shave close enough or a combo of the two. This is a rugged, well made shaver. The quality of this shaver versus lesser cost units and brands is evident in every facet of it's construction and operation. It works like a finely engineered machine. If you take shaving seriously, this is the shaver for you. My only concern with this product is with the cost, it's not cheap. I know reviews aren't really supposed to be based on cost as prices change but you should do some math before considering this pricey shaver. Lets say you use a high end razor with replaceable cartridges, pick one of the top of the line with 4-5 blades that really shaves super close. The razor: $10-$15 and comes with 1 razor cartridge Replaceable cartridges: they seem to cost from $3-$5 each, depending on where you buy them. So, that means $15 for the razor and $50-$60 a year on cartridges assuming you use a new one each month. Less if you make the cartridges last longer than a month or find a good deal on them. So, not only does this shaver cost a lot, it costs more than buying cartridges each year to use - they suggest you buy a $70 shaver head each year to replace the one built in. I dunno if that math works out frankly. I hope Phillips doesn't send a hit squad out on me. Anyways.... Pros of the Philips Norelco 1250x/40 SensoTouch 3d Electric Shaver: Very close, smooth shave. The triple floating heads actually let you get anywhere you need to shave. Easy clean up, pop the shaver heads & rinse under water. I know, crazy! Charges fast, lasts a long time. Cool digital readouts for charging status & battery. Can use it in the shower (or so it says, I am not brave enough to try!). Can use dry or with shaving cream / gel. Comes with a nice charging stand and a zip up travel case and a small brush. Very handy for travel, no need to pack a razor and gel / cream. Has a built in trimmer, very nice and easy to use. Cons: It's a sealed unit & rechargeable batteries have a life span. One day the battery will die and you will either send it in for a new one or toss it and buy a new shaver. Most batteries like this last 2-3 years tops before they stop holding a charge. That's my experience. The manual says to replace the shaving heads once a year which, I believe, cost about $70. So that means you are spending $70 a year to use this shaver at the optimum performance. I dunno about that math frankly. That's more than just buying a year's worth of top of the line razor cartridges each year. Comes with the standard \\"please give this shaver 21 days of usage to let your face get used to it...\\" I am in the first week of that 21 days. Some irritation on my neck from the shaver. Hope it gets better. To get a really close shave, which I like, this shaver doesn't actually save me any time. Lathering up my face & using a razor doesn't really take any more or less time plus I still get a closer shave with a top of the line razor cartridge.
  91. This is a gift for my husband. He loves it. He used to have another razor from Norelco similar to this one but a grade lower. The attachment shaver thingy will need to be attached and remove to use. After a while it becomes loose. He loves how this one you don't need to remove the shaver part is attached on to the body. The upgrade is worth it.

Much more quiet than the corded one that died after 7 years of use. And I love the close shave of these blades. Would definitely recommend. And I loved the price Amazon had.
  93. I used to just shave every few days. I don't have very thick hair growth, and I have always hated using an electric razor. Up until recently, I hated electric razors because they were hard to clean. In the last year, I've had the chance to use several electric razors and I've been surprised with how much they've improved in the last ten years. Among the 7 or 8 razors I've tried out this year, the Norelco 1250 is by far the best for how close of a shave it gives me. I had no razor irritation or burn from using the product, and it really glides smoothly over my face. It handles curves and the soft skin of my neck very easily. The best part about the razor though, is how easy it is to clean. I just hold the blades under the water and it's cleaned out in less than ten seconds. I don't have to mess with tiny brushes or cans of air to get all of the hair out of the nooks and crannies of it.
  94. This is my best Philips shaver ever. And Made in Holland! I have owned & used 6-7 Philips shavers over the past 50 years. I have only ever used electric shavers, never a blade, apart from the odd time when I'd left my trusty Philips at home. Without exception they have all been reliable shavers, each newer one an improvement on the previous model. My previous model a Coolskin, I thought could not be surpassed. I generally used it dry, only using the 'wet' shave occasionally. Now I've used the Norelco, the old one will be consigned to the shaver graveyard. The Norelco is such an improvement the difference is truly amazing. A really close shave, and so quick & quiet. Full marks to the manufacturers for a real state-of-art shaver. I am raving to all my mates.

I have always used Norelco Shavers with good results,until now. My previous Norelco was an Arcitec, and I was very pleased with it, and planned to go on line and get another like it.I was getting two weeks of shaves on that unit before recharging. When I read about the 1250x/40, it sounded like an upgraded version of the Arcitec, so I thought I would try it. What a disappointment! Yes it is quieter, but I find it is harder to shave above my lip as it has no give, and the poor battery life makes it inconvenient.   96. This shaver gives a more comfortable shave than the older models and it has very good battery life before it needs to be recharged. It is also easy to clean. You need to go slowly with it and I take two passes, the second one \\"against the grain\\", to get a close shave. I have been using this razor for a few months and I am very happy with it.
  97. I have a Braun 3 Series shaver that has the cleaning system. It cuts well and I was pretty much content with it. However as it started to get older, I knew I had to spend the money to buy a new foil and cutter. My brother had a Norelco and I tried it and liked it a lot. I decided on getting the Senso Touch 3d after seeing a $30 coupon on Amazon which made me choose it over the 2D. What I like a lot about this shaver are the following. After having a noisy Braun shaver that shed all the hairs to the floor or bathroom sink, it was very refreshing to have a quieter shaver that held the hairs more effectively than the Braun. With less noise, vibration, and lighter, it offers a more enjoyable shave. Being able to rinse it in the sink was also welcome. The Braun cleaning system is very good but expensive. The liquid evaporates inside the cleaning unit as well even when you don't use it. The Norelco power indicator is very nice, an it is comfortable to hold. Cutting: I will be honest, no electric shaver cuts as close as a Merkur razor using a Art of Shaving quality badger brush and their wonderful cream. Don't even bother with the cheap cream at the store that has alcohol in it. I also refuse to pay $160 and higher for a high end Braun shaver. I found the Norelco cuts very well. Like many have said, you don't have to push hard to get a good shave. I really like this shaver and the way it cuts. It is not super close, but it is close enough for daily use. I tried the Remington but the high speed of the motor caused more friction and made my face red. The slower motor of the Norelco does the job. This heads are also an upgrade to some of the older Norelco's. I highly recommend this shaver.
  98. Initially it irritated my skin, but that passed in about a week. Now it is so much smoother than my old razor and still - doesn't irritate my skin at all! :)
  99. I've accumulated quite a few electric razors over the years, with the three most recent being the new models from Norelco, Braun and Panasonic. So, thought I'd do a comparison to perhaps help those who are debating between these high-end models.<br /><br />But first let's get a basic question out of the way: do you have to spend this much to get a good shave from an electric shaver? Absolutely not. Lower-end models such as the Braun Series 5, the 7000 and 8000 Norelco series and the Panasonic ArcIV are great shavers. What you get for the extra money is a slight improvement in the shave, a bit better design, and a few somewhat useful bells and whistles.<br /><br />Build quality - all are very nicely put together. The Braun feels the most substantial; the 3D feels the most \\"plasticy.\\"<br /><br />Sound - the 3D runs very quietly; the Braun and Panasonic are far more \\"buzzy\\" but not too loud.<br /><br />Overall feel - for me, the Braun feels the most comfortable to hold. Easy to grip even if your hands are wet. The Panasonic is a close second. The 3D feels the most awkward. Not horrible, but not all that comfortable either.<br /><br />Dry shave: closeness - this is a tough call, with the Braun and the Panasonic both providing very close shaves. The 3D does a pretty good job, but my face does not feel as smooth as with the others.<br /><br />Dry shave: speed - the 3D is the clear winner here. Just mows through my beard, with a total shave time of less than 3 min. The Panasonic takes about 4 min for a good shave; the Braun clocks in at about 5 min.<br /><br />Dry shave: neck - this is the most difficult area for most shavers, and all of these models left a few errant hairs here and there. The 3D did the best but it comes at the expense of some irritation (see the next note). The Braun and Panasonic are about equal.<br /><br />Dry shave: comfort - Braun is the winner for me, followed by the Panasonic. Zero redness even in the more sensitive spots (jaw line and neck). The 3D left me with some red spots on my neck. Nothing severe, but it is clearly a notch below the others on the comfort meter.<br /><br />Wet shave - this is limited to just the Panasonic and the 3D. I'm not a big fan of wet shaving, but both of these do a very good job. The Panny works best with a very thin layer of gel-type cream; the 3D works best with a heavier lather (I got good results with Edge). Both provided close shaves, with the Panny a bit more gentle than the 3D. But, the 3D did a better job on the neck and jaw line.<br /><br />** Update: Just tried the new Remington Alphagel shaving cream and that works very well with both the Panny and the Norelco. The scent is a bit heavy (menthol) but the no-foam consistency is a perfect match for a wet electric shave. Much better than any other shave cream I've tried. I reviewed the Alphagel if you want more info.<br /><br />Maneuverabilit - this is where the Braun really shines for me. I have a mustache, and edging it with the Braun is a piece of cake. The 3D takes some practice, but it can do a decent job. Worst by far was the Panasonic - the huge head makes it very hard to create a clean edge around the `stash.<br /><br />Auto cleaning - I love the cleaning station from Braun. Works well, cleans well, and the razor comes out lemony-fresh. The Panasonic cleaning station is OK, but is louder, takes longer, and the water-based cleaning solution is not as effective. I can't comment on the 3D station since the model I bought didn't come with it.<br /><br />Manual cleaning - both the Panasonic and 3D are very easy to clean manually. They actually don't need the auto cleaning station (although it is handy for storage for the Panny). The cutters are removable from the 3D (unlike the Arcitec models) for extra cleaning every so often. The Braun can be cleaned with water, but it's hard to get it very clean since the cutter block is a single unit.<br /><br />Lots more that I could say about these razors, but this review is already way too long. If I had to pick just one, I'd go with the Braun. While not perfect, it excels in several areas and feels the best. It also offers three settings (gentle, normal and intensive) that vary the speed of the cutters, a feature the other two lack. I find that very helpful. Plus, replacement heads are easily available and often discounted (as are the cleaning cartridges). But, the 3D and the Panasonic are also very good shavers and will get the job done. If you are willing to spend the money, any one of these would be a good choice.<br /><br />But, you have to learn how to use an electric razor properly to get a good shave. Some quick tips:<br /><br />1) Don't press hard - use an easy touch. If the heads are getting warm or hot, you're pressing too hard.<br />2) Shave against the grain when using a foil; shave in circular motions when using a rotary.<br />3) Stretch your skin taut when shaving your neck<br />4) Wait at least an hour after getting up before shaving (everyone's face gets a bit puffy when sleeping).<br /><br />Happy shaving!ady way too long. If I had to pick just one, I'd go with the Braun. While not perfect, it excels in several areas and feels the best. It also offers three settings (gentle, normal and intensive) that vary the speed of the cutters, a feature the other two lack. I find that very helpful. Plus, replacement heads are easily available and often discounted (as are the cleaning cartridges). But, the 3D and the Panasonic are also very good shavers and will get the job done. If you are willing to spend the money, any one of these would be a good choice.<br /><br />But, you have to learn how to use an electric razor properly to get a good shave. Some quick tips:<br /><br />1) Don't press hard - use an easy touch. If the heads are getting warm or hot, you're pressing too hard.<br />2) Shave against the grain when using a foil; shave in circular motions when using a rotary.<br />3) Stretch your skin taut when shaving your neck<br />4) Wait at least an hour after getting up before shaving (everyone's face gets a bit puffy when sleeping).<br /><br />Happy shaving!

  103. Update as of May 29, 2011: Well, it's been almost 6 months, and still shaving bump (ingrown hairs) free. Still a great shave. Getting about 28-30 days per charge using the charging stand ONLY when the battery shows flat.<br /><br />Would still recommend without reservation.<br /><br />I've used many different electric razors over the years, from all of the major companies. This is, by far, the best of the lot. Let's do some pros and cons, and then I'll go into detail.<br /><br />PROS:<br />Shaves extremely close<br />Quick charge<br />Easy to clean<br />I get about 3 weeks per charge (shaving about 3-4 minutes daily)<br />Reminder to clean<br />Travel lock<br />NO MORE SHAVING BUMPS (aka ingrown hairs)<br /><br />CONS:<br />Feels a bit odd in my hand at first (I have big hands)<br />No corded shaving, must use charger stand<br />Replacement heads a bit pricey, but I know where to look to find them cheaper<br /><br />OK, let's talk about this. The shaves I'm getting are extremely close, and seem to be safety razor comparable. I have a heavy beard, and I have smooth skin well past 8 PM after an early morning shave, and that ain't bad.<br /><br />Charging is very quick, but you must use the charger stand, no corded shaving capabilities with this. I don't leave the charger plugged in, I believe constant charging reduces battery life, at least in my experience. I've gotten 6-8 years from previous Norelco shavers using this technique as opposed to constant charging.<br /><br />Cleaning is very simple. First you get a little reminder light (looks like a water faucet) every other shave to remind you to clean it. Just pop up all three heads, run it under water, and you're done.<br /><br />There's a travel lock, which is basically an extended push of the power button. This locks the shaver so you don't run the risk of having a dead battery on arrival. Been there and ended up shaving with my wife's razor due to not bringing the charging cord (this on a different razor than the 1250X).<br /><br />I suffered from shaving bumps, also known as ingrown hairs. My beard tends to be curly, and the hairs would curve under and cause bumps growing under the skin laterally. I don't know why but this has stopped completely with the 1250X. Very happy with that outcome even though I hadn't expected it. A very nice bonus.<br /><br />The unit does feel a little strange in my hand. Not bad, just different. I have large hands, and this is probably the reason. But I can maneuver the razor all over my face with no problem. I guess this is more a personal observation than a complaint, but I present it for your review and information.<br /><br />You must use the charger stand in order to charge the razor. No way to just pack the razor and cord and not worry about charging. But this is a very minor quibble, and not one worth taking a star off for. As I said, I don't leave the charger stand plugged in, I believe that reduces the battery life.<br /><br />The replacement heads are expensive, but if you look around you can find them for less. Try a warehouse club for example. As far as the heads themselves, I believe there is a reminder light that comes on after a year to remind you to change the heads. Not close to that time period, so no way to tell you if that works. In my experience though I don't wait for recommended times. If the razor feels \\"wrong\\" I replace the heads. Better shaving that way.<br /><br />All in all I recommend this razor without reservation. Well worth the cost.be curly, and the hairs would curve under and cause bumps growing under the skin laterally. I don't know why but this has stopped completely with the 1250X. Very happy with that outcome even though I hadn't expected it. A very nice bonus. The unit does feel a little strange in my hand. Not bad, just different. I have large hands, and this is probably the reason. But I can maneuver the razor all over my face with no problem. I guess this is more a personal observation than a complaint, but I present it for your review and information. You must use the charger stand in order to charge the razor. No way to just pack the razor and cord and not worry about charging. But this is a very minor quibble, and not one worth taking a star off for. As I said, I don't leave the charger stand plugged in, I believe that reduces the battery life. The replacement heads are expensive, but if you look around you can find them for less. Try a warehouse club for example. As far as the heads themselves, I believe there is a reminder light that comes on after a year to remind you to change the heads. Not close to that time period, so no way to tell you if that works. In my experience though I don't wait for recommended times. If the razor feels \\"wrong\\" I replace the heads. Better shaving that way. All in all I recommend this razor without reservation. Well worth the cost.

  107. I'm 58 with very sensitive skin. I recently bought two different manual razors, one that even had an adjustment for the double edge blade. Both cut my face because my skin is so sensitive or thin. A single blade disposable razor cut my face much less than the two much more expensive double edge blade ones. On to Philips Norelco 1250x. Many years ago I used a Norelco rotary razor. It was okay, but the cleaning was a chore. After reading more reviews on the new electric Norelco rotary shavers I decided to purchase the Philips Norelco triple head 1250x. I am so glad I did. Here's how I use it. 1st) Run very warm water from the showhead unto my facial hair for a minute or so. 2nd) Lather a shaving cream like Proraso shaving cream unto my facial hair. 3rd) Pull the one piece triplehead unit off the charged up Norelco shaver and hold the triplehead unit under very warm running water from the showerhead for a couple seconds. 4th) Line it up correctly and push the one piece triplehead unit unto the charged up Norelco 1250x shaver. 5th) Quickly and easily shave all my facial hair off. When I'm done both my facial hair and thin layer of shaving cream are gone from my face. 6th) I pull the one piece triplehead unit off the charged up Norelco shaver and pull each rotary head from the center up and outward to open up the lid on each rotary head. The blades are secure and don't seem to be in danger of falling out. 7th) I then run the opened up triplehead unit under the running very warm water from the showerhead to throughly clean out the cut hair and shaving cream holder as well as the rotary razors. 8th) I place the now cleaned onened up triplehead unit upside down on a thick cloth to dry and I place the hand helded unit in the charger to charge up again. Pros: My fastest and closest shave ever. I've never cut myself with this shaver. It even shaves right under my nose. It misses nothing. My face feels great afterwards. Cons: For a wet shave like I do - none.

An of course, it's very expensive. I justified it by telling myself that something I'd use every day for several years is worth an extra $50-$75. The instruction manual is entertaining. They recommend obsessive cleaning that is totally unnecessary, and suggest cleaning the head under hot water, and sternly warn against getting hurt from the hot water. Apparently men old enough to shave still need to be reminded about this. Sounds like lawyers. I find it to be a quality device that I'd recommend to anyone willing to pay the price.

Personally I get a shave that is as good as a blade when I use shaving cream with it. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it outworks my old razor. The 3d heads are great. As far as the different versions of the Sensotouch 3d, I decided to go with the cheapest version. If you look on the chart at the bottom of product pages, the only difference between the most expensive version all the way down to the cheapest one is VERY minor difference. And these differences won't affect the quality of the shave one bit. Like the most expensive one has a zinc finish and a \\"luxury\\" travel bag. Some of them have personal cleaning systems that you don't really need. Just make sure you open each head individually after each shave and wash them with hot water. This is what I did with my previous shaver and it lasted a long while. Actually it still works, I just wanted to try a newer version to see if I was missing out on anything and I am glad I decided to try these out. Great razor, great price. Not too big either, it easily shaves every place on my face. The only downside is the pop up razor. Maybe I'm just used to the pop up on my Smart Touch XL but I was a little disappointed with this one. When you use it, it seems like the 3d rotary heads get in the way when using the pop up shaver. Only a minor mistake and I can always use the one on my Smart Touch but beware this is a big factor in purchasing a razor.
  118. I have a thick beard and I shave my head as well... WOW!!! What a great machine... I shave in a fraction of the time it took my old one and this one is very very VERY comfortable. I love it!! I know it costs more, but it's so SO worth it!!
  119. I received a sensor touch razor as a gift and loved it. After a year I needed to replace the whole head. Blades were not available and the head was discontinued. It's even quieter than my Dad's old Sunbeam that he used many years ago. Clean up is a breeze. Rinsing it during shaving, and then raising the three heads and rinsing them, completely cleans the whole shaver. Recharging is very simple and easy using the stand and cord. Though I sent in all to the documentation, Philips Norelco denied my rebate stating that I already got a rebate at the time of purchase. However I never had a manufacturer's rebate at the time of purchase!! I have no recourse now. Amazon handled the transaction just fine, it's Philips Norelco that is at fault. Beware of any holiday or other rebates from Philips Norelco as they will not honor it and not give you a means to appeal. I'm not the only person. A blog that I checked out recently had about 500 people who complained about the exact same thing!!! I would rate the razer about 3.5 stars for effectiveness on an absolute scale, I would rate it 1.0 stars as value for the money, and I would rate Philips Norelco at 0 stars for its lack of ethics and refusal to honor its legal and fiduciary responsibilities.
  136. This is probably one of the best shavers I have ever had. Originally, I had a Phillips Norelco 7130 shaver which has 3 heads but all connected on one platform unlike this one. One of my main complaints with this shaver is the fact that if your hair is longer than a millimeter, you will get pulled hairs all over the place. OUCH! Lots of CRIES for HELP!!! That is no fun. Also, the shaver works in wet situations, but you really need lotion to ensure your skin does not get totally dry. With this new SensoTouch shaver, your problems are solved.<br /><br />The vibration on my original Norelco was like holding a jet engine. I could feel the vibration in my teeth as I shaved, and it was not a pleasant experience. I also had to rub over my skin numerous times to get the shaver to pick up all of my hair, and even then I usually ended up using a manual blade to trim any close excess.<br /><br />Compare that to this shaver - The shave is fast. You will not have much extra hairs on your neck after you use this shaver. It seems to glide smoothly over my skin and cuts very close. It works great when going against the grain. It is great on the chin where you will have difficulty with a flat head. All of my family members love touching my face with this shaver - before, my wife would complain that my face would be scratchy unless I used a razor to manually shave close to my skin - now she cant really tell the difference.<br /><br />There's some fancy technology built into the device that is really for marketing purposes. The 3 heads move independently and while they are very \\"cool\\" - I find that they do not really make a huge difference in the shave on the side of the face. The whole head moves around which is good for your wrist but again is more of a \\"gimmick\\" than anything else.<br /><br />We are not talking about newfangled technology that CREATES A SCANTILY CLAD WOMAN TO REMOVE YOUR HAIR, instead it's just some heads that flex to accommodate your face. It has a good heft in your hands and will feel comfortable when you are shaving your face.<br /><br />The fantastic thing about this razor is that it has a voltage function that allows you to convert from 110 to 240 volts AC which is perfect for international travels. I know some of the other reviewers have commented on the issue with international travel, but I can say this works perfectly abroad as I have used it in other countries. This works perfectly in England, for one.<br /><br />The charge is great - give it one hour from a dead charge and you're good to go. It will charge while you leave it for the next day so you are always at a full charge when you pick it up. There's a battery indicator which I find to be VERY HELPFUL on my shavers - I do not like to go a few days without charging then have to worry about whether I need to charge this up or not. Regardless, this guy lasts at least 17 days depending on usage (obviously the actual ability is more like an hour nonstop) so you could take it on a vacation and not even need a charger with you! (I don't recommend that... sometimes it's a good idea to throw caution to the wind - this is not one of those times. Pack the charger.)<br /><br />The instructions are very clear. Norelco also tells you to wait a few weeks to let your body get used to it, but I found that my face reacted positively within a few days. YAY NORELCO! It runs well with water - I was able to use it in the shower and was able to grip the razor without qualms. I found that on previous shavers, it might slip around in my hand on the smooth surfaces. No issue with that one here. Comes with a pouch for travel.<br /><br />If you are a picky shaver and enjoy shaving with shaving cream, you can even use that here, as the shaver has special stops to prevent shaving cream from destroying the system as it will with other shavers. GO NORELCO!<br /><br />I compared this guy to my manual razor - Gillette Fusion - which requires that I shave again every few days. I often cut myself at least once or twice while shaving with the fusion, and it is time consuming to pre-lotion, lather, apply evenly, shave off, put on a bandaid, etc etc. The electric shave rolls the skin up and forces the hairs into the blade, which then slices it off nicely without any pain.<br /><br />One negative is that you have to hand-clean each head which is easy to do only sometimes (if it cooperates). This requires opening up each section and cleaning it which, if you are in a rush, feels laborious and time consuming. This is in marked contrast to my original Phillips which was one single head that popped open and allowed me to easily rinse it out. BOOM. Done.<br /><br />If you are a fast operator in the morning, then to make up for this, consider buying this shaver with the Jet Clean system as well, which will set you back an extra $50 plus the cost of the jet clean solution (there are two options for this but I'm referring to the cheaper one). Consider this option if you do not want to have to clean the shaver manually and you want the ease and comfort of just popping it in the cleaner and only needing to replace the solution every so often. The Jet system will also lubricate and charge the shaver as well, so it's a good buy if you can keep it in one place - traveling with it might be a greater burden. That option is found here: [[ASIN:B003V37Z9W Philips Norelco 1250xcc/42 SensoTouch 3d Electric Shaver with Jet Clean System, Black]]<br /><br />One final note-this IS an expensive shaver. Compare it to a shaver that costs $75 or $90 dollars, and you're still spending $60 more on a shaver. If you save yourself just 2-3 minutes a day by using this shaver, and you shave every 3 days, that's about 6 hours a year. At a very conservative rate of $10 an hour, you've saved yourself the money after one year of usage. That really adds up over the lifetime of this shaver!!! If you save yourself money, time, effort, and convenience on this shaver, then it's really a solid investment. WARREN BUFFET WOULD AGREE.<br /><br />If this review was helpful, please consider a positive vote. I am happy to provide answers about the shaver and my experience, so feel free to ask any questions you may have!
  137. I've not been overly happy with the cheaper Philips products in the past and had changed to a microfoil shaver which I had been using for the past 12 months.   138. This is a great electric shaver. I've used Norelco products for a lot of years now, (my last one used the \\"goo\\" cartridges) but this one is by far the best. It is super quiet and the battery life is amazing. Clean-up is simple and quick. Yes you have to open each head individually, but you don't have to take the head apart to clean it; just hold it under the faucet and let the water wash it clean. I've used this shaver both wet and dry and I actually prefer dry. My beard is somewhat coarse and this shaver just works best for me this way. I charged it when I first got it and then used it every day for almost a month before I had to charge it again. Once the battery indicator turned red, I was still able to use it another four days. When the battery drains far enough the shaver just turns off and has to be charged again. I do miss the \\"goo\\" but by far, this is the best Norelco I've ever owned.

  152. I bought this shaver for my father-in-law. After one month it stopped working. But it didn't just stop working. When I looked closely at the shaver i saw a very poorly constructed device. How so? I flipped up the shaving heads and turned the shaver on. The drivers were spinning strongly, but there was no contact between the heads and the drivers when the heads were snapped back into place. And because there was no contact with even one of the heads there was no spinning just the buzz of the drivers underneath going like crazy. The device did not feel like a precision instrument- and at its price, it should. It felt cheap, and its 1-month performance demonstrated to me that today's Norelco is not the Norelco of old.
  153. just avery good razor

  156. My worst fear about getting an(other) Electric Razor was the inability of being able to achieve results around my neck and jawline. I am ecstatic to state that this razor did an awesome job. My razor previous to this was a Braun 8585 which I stopped using about 3 years ago because it never seemed to work around the neckline/jaw area. I have been using Gillette razors since I started shaving 18 years back, outside of the short periods of time I have given electric razors a shot.<br /><br />I understand that it can take time (2-4 weeks) for an Electric Razor to start showing good results and I was expecting a crappy first shave. However, I was amazed that not only did I get a really close shave but the irritation to my skin was minimal around the neck/jawline area. While shaving with standard razors I do not shave against the grain because it irritates my skin. I normally shave with the grain (up to down) and then shave sideways (left to right). What I was hoping for is to get a similar result while dry shaving with the 1250x and I can state that it did for me.<br /><br />The only thing that is a little disappointing is that the jet-clean is not standard for a razor that is close to $200. That being said, as cleaning the razor manually was fairly straightforward I still give the razor 5/5.<br /><br />Pros<br />- Really close dry shave. My dry shave with the 1250x was as close as a wet shave with my Gillette Pro Fusion.<br /><br />Con<br />- For an expensive razor it should have a standard jet cleaning system.
  157. My personal experience: i have had it for a week. It is the best, lightest and quietest electric shaver that I have used.(I have owned about 8 Norelcos in the last 30 years.) it is superior to the Braun 7 which is heavier and slower.   159. I've been using electric shavers for over 35 years. I've used every major brand made. Phillips/Norelco has finally gotten it right with the 1250X40 SensoTouch 3D shaving system. I'm very impressed with this shaver (And I'm not impressed very easily). In the past I've bought the top line shaver from the three major shaver manufacturers (Braun, Panasonic, Phillips/Norelco) & tried them out side by side. I've always felt the linear foil screen shavers made by Braun & Panasonic gave a closer shave, that is until now. This SensoTouch 3D shaving system gives just as close a shave as the linear foil screen shavers by Braun & Panasonic. The Phillips/Norelco shavers have always been less irritating to the skin than the foil screen shavers. So if you have sensitive skin that is easily irritated by shaving, you will appreciate any of the Phillips/Norelco shavers. This shaver has a quick 1 hour to full charge feature. If you let the battery run down, a 3-5 minute charge will get you a full shave. You must use the charger stand to charge the shaver. This is a bit of a negative for the shaver. I sometimes travel for two weeks at a time, and so will have to carry the bulky charger stand in my shaver bag. (My last Braun shaver had a cord that could plug into the charger stand or directly into the shaver. The cord was small & easily fit in my travel shaver bag. Phillips/Norelco should provide this feature on a shaver this expensive). There is an LED indicator in the handle that indicates battery charge level when the shaver is turned on. This shaver is very light weight, easy to grip & feels good in your hand. When I first turned it on, I thought it wasn't working properly, so I turned it off & back on again. I finally held it next to my ear & could hear that it was running. This shaver is unbelievably quiet! For my first shave I wanted to give the shaver a real workout & so I let my beard grow for a full two and a half days. It cut through my beard with little effort. One nice feature I have noticed about the Phillips/Norelco shavers is that none of them have ever grabbed or pulled the hair on my face. This will sometimes occur with some shavers if your beard has grown for a few days. It took a little longer to cut my two day beard than my old Braun shaver which has the loud but very fast cutting linear motor. However, I got a very close comfortable shave. The SensoTouch 3D shaving system excels at shaving your neck & jaw line. This is the biggest challenge for any electric shaver. With the Panasonic & Braun shavers, I frequently had to go over & over these areas to get those stubborn long hairs. The SensoTouch 3D shaving system easily removes the long hairs due to the way the heads conform to your neck & jaw line. This is a major benefit for the 1250X40. The high speed linear motors of the Braun & Panasonic shavers will plow through a thick heavy beard faster than the Phillips/Norelco shavers. However, your overall shave time will be about the same since the SensoTouch 3D shaving system will shave your neck & jaw line without repeated strokes. The SensoTouch 3D shaving system's independent floating heads also makes it easier to shave the area between your mustache & nose. This was a real negative on previous versions of Phillips/Norelco shavers. It is now much easier & with a little practice I'm able to shave right up to my side burns & mustache without that dreaded \\"ooops\\". This shaver is extremely easy to clean. Simply flip up the heads & run warm water over them & they come completely clean. Another nice feature that your wife will love, is that the stubble stays inside the heads. No more dirty sink or countertop. This shaver can be used wet or dry. Which is best? Although I haven't tried this shaver wet, my past experience has always been that a dry shave is closer & more comfortable with an electric shaver. Always wash your face with soap & water & dry completely before shaving. This will give the closest & most comfortable shave. Will the 1250X40 shave as close as a safety blade razor? No. No electric shaver is able to cut the hair below the skin like a blade razor. However any of the top line shavers made by Panasonic, Braun or Phillips/Norelco will come very close. (Blade razor shave = 10, Phillips/Norelco 1250X40 = 9.5) The Phillips/Norelco 1250X40 is a quick and easy shave system. It will give you a close smooth shave. If shaving ever irritates your skin you're going to love this shaver. It is the most comfortable shave I've ever gotten. BTW. Every electric shaver manufacturer says to try their shaver for at least 30 days. Your face will have time to adjust to the new shaver. True or False? At first I thought this was just another empty sales pitch. However after many years & many different shavers I find this to be true. I'm not sure if it is due to the fact of your face adjusting to the shaver or the fact that you gain experience in using that particular shaver. But the quality of your shave will improve over time using a new shaver. So don't throw in the towel for at least 30 days.
  160. I like this! Very useful!<br />I use this every day. And this stuff make me comfortable life.<br />I think I bought this one cheapest<br />Thanks
  161. Been using Norelco's since I first began shaving. I've been using it for 7 months and I like it. Not sure if I buy that 3D is best hype but it does shave better in less time then my old Smart Touch XL razor. I do dislike the charging cradle though. It's bulky and lightweight and uses suction cups to stabilize itself. And it's a requirement to use the cradle instead of attaching the cable directly to the shaver. The two times or so a month I need to use it's not worth the keep it on display all the time. It adds considerable bulk to my charger drawer. Another thing I hate is the hair collection chambers. A light tap with a finger is enough to send finely chopped hair all over your pants when I am not shaving under a sink - which is often. It gets tolerable over time. At first it was difficult for me to clean, but I gotten good at it: with hot water run over the blades while the chambers are closed most of your hair should get pushed out. Then open the chambers and run the hot water under the blades and all over the chamber floor. Make sure it irrigates well while drying out.
  162. I bought that for my boyfriend. i think it is really worth it. i saw so many review about that. Every usersaid that it is good and work well. As well as it has good design!!! After that i decided to buy it. it will be great christmas gift. my boyfriend might love that!!! :)
  163. First, I highly recommend buying through Amazon. The merchants who use Amazon to sell their products will give you exceptional service. Amazon demands the highest quality service be given to customers who buy via the Amazon site and merchants will go the distance to insure customers are happy. Products are often shipped without shipping charges and products can arrive in 2 or 3 days. Amazon is the best retailer on the internet.<br /><br />I have used a Braun electrical shaver for years, a good and reliable shaver. However, the Norelco GyroFlex 3D Shaver is a better shaver. The Norelco is quiet and shaves closer in less time. The Norelco shaver can shave a wet, lathered beard almost as close as a safety razor blade. However, wet-lathered shaving requires light pressure and fewer passes to achieve a close shave. The Braun shaver was uncomfortable when shaving my head, the Norelco is so comfortable and quick. If you want the best electric shaver, buy a Norelco. Finally, Norelco gave me 6 additional months warranty for registering on their internet site, extending the warranty to 21/2 years.
  164. I've been using an older style Norelco for 5 years and after replacing the blades several times, decided I would give this a try. After two weeks, I still haven't decided how much I like this. I have medium growth and the shave is definitely closer than my last Norelco and somewhat smoother. Yet, the motor is less powerful and so it takes longer to shave. The worst problem, other than the fact there is no cord which several other reviewers have noted, is that the pop up shaver is virtually worthless. I've used this feature a lot for trimming sideburns, eyebrows and the hair that grows over the ears in between trips to the barber. I'm sufficiently disappointed that I'm actually thinking of returning the shaver and going back to shaving cream and a razor.

The speed and closeness of the shave was great.<br />Move ahead to two weeks ago, the shaver head broke, replacement parts about $70. (Geez does nothing last? It actually provides as close or closer shave than the Braun foil shavers but with speed. Cleaning is a simple hot water rinse. If you want the top of the line this is the one.<br />Update: I started shaving in the shower with foam...this thing is an engineering marvel...close as a blade and no cuts. Awesome.

  172. This really seems like a great razor and, from most of the other reviews, it would seem to be. But, for me, it doesn't work well enough. I was hoping it would be a replacement for a regular razor, but it seems like such a thing is still not possible with an electric. It does a very good, almost excellent job on my cheeks but it is less than stellar on my chin and in the mustache area. For the neck area, it is terrible. I've tried it with and without shaving cream and just cannot get a close shave anywhere outside of the cheeks. Furthermore, it irritates my neck even more than a regular razor because I have to go over the area so many times. My next plan is to use a straight razor for the neck and try this for everything else. It does say in the guide that the razor should improve after a while. I've used it three times, so I'll give it a little more time to see if it improves.
  173. PROS - best shave of all shavers I've owned, including several Norelcos. Fast, comfortable, and smooth. This seems to be their best set of shaving heads. - long battery life CONS - MAJOR CON FOR TRAVEL: the charger plugs into the stand, which then charges the shaver through some contact points. You *cannot* directly plug the charger into the shaver, meaning if you want to be able to charge it while traveling, plan on packing the large charging stand too. It can do quite a few shaves on one charge, so maybe you risk not bringing the charger. My solution is to bring my older, lower-end Norelco that plugs directly into the shaver. - small head compartments require frequent cleaning to clear out accumulated hairs. It's not that hard - pop all 3 heads and then use running water in the sink - but it has to be done more often than the lower-end Norelcos with bigger compartments. Another minor issue: with the lower-end single-head Norelcos, it's easy to dab a towel after washing to get most of the water and facilitate drying. Not easily done with this one with the way the 3 heads open as well as many metal snag points for the towel. So plan on drying it a long time with beads of water all over the heads and compartments. Probably not much of an issue at home, but again could be annoying if you're packing it after use for travel. - The heads being so elevated above the trimmer makes the trimmer a little awkward to us, as the heads are often bumping into some part of your face while you're using the trimmer.
  174. I have attempted to like electric shavers in the past with no success. Then, I saw this product advertised on television and decided to take yet another swing at electric. Wow! What a difference. I use it with water and cream, and it's better than shaving with a blade. It takes several weeks for your face to adjust to the system, but then it's terrific. My only beef is that the company offered a substantial rebate with the purchase and I'm still waiting after 2 months.
  175. The shave is SO much better than my previous razor. My only complaint is the charger. In order to charge, you have to use the stand with the power cable. That's fine most of the time but it means I have to bring the stand when I travel (unless it's a short trip). That's probably not a problem for most users and it didn't stop me from giving it five stars. But it's something to keep in mind.

  187. UPDATE October 27, 2013:<br /><br />After 2 years and 2 months of owning this shaver, it died. It now displays a flashing red exclamation point and refuses to turn on. It is now 2 months after the 2 year warranty, so it seems I am completely out of luck at this point. It's as if it was designed to fail right after the warranty.<br /><br />I sent an email to Phillips Norelco describing the problem. I'll post an update here if/when they respond.<br /><br />There is no indication in the troubleshooting manual what a flashing red exclamation point means, so I have no idea what's going on with it. There is a description about what to do if you find that it's lighting up that indicator along with two others at the same time, but it doesn't tell you what it is if it's just that one indicator and nothing else.<br /><br />I handled this shaver with kid gloves. I washed it after every use. I never mishandled it. Never dropped it. It was working fine yesterday, and now it won't turn on.<br /><br />The shaver was actually very good. Easily the best I've ever had. My shave yesterday was as good as the first shave I had with the device when it was brand new. It didn't dull in all that time.<br /><br />I originally gave it 5 stars. But I have since demoted it to 3 stars due to the fact that it died after just 2 years. My last shaver was a Braun, and it lasted around 10 years. Even then, it was just the rechargeable battery that needed replacement, and it still worked when plugged into the wall socket.<br /><br />My original review follows:<br /><br />This is my first rotary shaver since I switched to foil shavers back in the mid-90's. Foil shavers have been pretty good for me, and the last one I had was the Braun series 5 foil shaver. I used one of those for probably 8 to 10 years, I think. For the past two years, it hasn't been able to hold a charge, and I had been using it while plugged in to the wall. When the cord starting to become loose, and the shaver spontaneously shut itself off many times during my shave, it was then that I realized I definitely needed to get myself a new shaver.<br /><br />The main problem I had with my Braun series 5 foil shaver was that it took about 10 to 12 minutes to get a good shave. I had to work at it, constantly rubbing my hand against my face and going back over the same area with my shaver. It was a good shave, but it required work. I wanted something that could shave in half the time.<br /><br />That's when I saw the Norelco 1250x/40 rotary shaver and thought I'd give it a try and see if rotary shavers were any better than foil ones. This one is their top of the line rotary shaver, so I figured it would be a good test. Alternatively, there's the Norelco Speed XL rotary shaver, which advertises its speed over all. But I figured I'd give the 1250x/40 a try first.<br /><br />I've now had the Norelco 1250x/40 for over 10 days. At first, I have to tell you, I was not impressed with this shaver. It just wasn't giving me a good shave. It took 16 minutes to shave, and even then it left some stubble. I just gave up, so it might have been 20 minutes or more of work just to get it to the point where my old foil shaver could get to. And because I was constantly going over and over the same areas, pressing harder and harder each time, it was leaving me with razor burn.<br /><br />I was ready to send it back yesterday, but I decided to give it another try. This time I decided to try using it with shaving cream rather than just dry skin. Would that help any? It actually made a HUGE difference!<br /><br />With the shaving cream, I was able to shave in just 2-3 minutes. It got my face clean and smooth with just one or two passes. It was one of the best shaves I've ever had. It was an even better shave than spending 15 minutes with my Braun series 5 foil (admittedly the foil shaver was dry while the Norelco was with shaving cream). There were only a couple areas which required me to go back over, but it was minor. It got 99% of the stubble in just 2 or 3 minutes.<br /><br />UPDATE... Several days after this review, I've been getting better and better at shaving with this shaver as I learn which parts of my face require a little more care. Now I don't seem to be missing any areas at all. I'm so amazed every morning how good my shave is that I ask my girlfriend to feel my face to see how smooth it is. You can't feel anything. It's just skin, no stubble at all. Even 8 hours later, much of my face remains stubble free. The chin and neck grow in fast, though, but that's biology, not the shaver's fault... I've timed my shave with this shaver, and I get to 5 minutes if I'm being careful to go slow and pay attention to detail. With my last shaver, it was taking 10-12 minutes on average. So this is a big improvement in speed, and it's a much closer shave.<br /><br />So I've decided not to return it after all, and I'm actually thinking this is the best shaver I've ever had. Without shaving cream, it just doesn't do a good job at all, in my opinion. That's what was surprising to me. I've never needed to use shaving cream before with electric shavers. But it's fine. I can accept having to use shaving cream if it means I can get a perfectly smooth shave in just a few minutes. That's a trade-off I'll take any day.<br /><br />As for cleaning the shaver, it's a breeze. I'm confused why reviewers here think it's hard to clean. It's not. You run the top part under water for 5 seconds, then you pop open the 3 heads and run them all under water for about 15 seconds. Then you give it a little shake and let it dry on its own. What is so hard about that? Cleaning out my old Braun series 5 foil shaver took several minutes, and it involved tediously using a brush to poke in between the holes in the foil, because oil and hair gunk would block the foil holes after a while. This Norelco 1250x/40 is much easier to clean by comparison. They really designed it well.<br /><br />I really like that it's a lithiumion battery and not nickle cadmium. That means you won't get the battery \\"memory effect\\". You can just charge it after every use rather than worrying about letting it run down completely before recharging it. My old shaver was like that, and I was always worried about running out of charge mid-way into my shave.<br /><br />Another huge plus in my mind is the fact that it's very quiet. My old Braun series 5 foil shaver was loud enough to annoy anyone sleeping in the next room. I can use the Norelco 1250x/40 without worrying about waking anyone up. That's nice.<br /><br />The beard trimmer part is not bad, either. A lot of people were upset that it looked like an afterthought instead of a well designed feature. They thought it should extend out further away from the rotary cutter head. Personally, I don't use the trimmer a lot. And if they designed it so that it protruded more than it does now, I think more people would have a problem with that. If you're finding yourself in need of the trimmer a lot, maybe you just need to get a stand-alone beard trimmer in addition to this. Even a $25 stand-alone trimmer would be better than the best built-in trimmer you can find out there.<br /><br />About the only negative things I'll say about this are: 1) the battery is not replaceable, 2) it's unable to use it corded (battery only operation), and 3) the charging stand is pretty easy to topple over. All of these negatives are acceptable to me, since it does give me such a good shave. But yes, having a corded feature would be much more welcomed. And the fact that you need to take the charging stand with you when you go on trips is annoying. I really wish the designers would have done that differently.<br /><br />Oh, and there is one more thing to talk about. The cost of the replacement heads is $60 at this time. That seems like a lot of money to be paying just for the heads. But I'm hoping they don't need to be replaced every 12-18 months like the manual says to do. My Braun series 5 foil cutter blocks definitely needed replacing every 6-9 months or so. But rotary cutter blades, I've heard, last a lot longer. A lot of people say they've never had to replace theirs. But who knows about the Norelco 1250x/40.<br /><br />So in summary:<br /><br />PROS:<br />+ Excellent close shave, with shaving cream.<br />+ Very fast shave in just 3 minutes, with shaving cream.<br />+ Lithium Ion battery.<br />+ Very easy to clean.<br />+ Very quiet.<br />+ Battery level indicator.<br />+ Looks nice.<br /><br />CONS:<br />- Need shaving cream if you want a fast and close shave with it.<br />- Battery is not replaceable. So, 3-5 year lifetime?<br />- Battery only operation, lacking a corded feature.<br />- Charging stand is easy to topple over.<br />- Need to take the charging stand with you on trips.<br />- Expensive head replacement.<br />- Expensive shaver.<br /><br />UPDATE... It's been a few weeks now since starting to use this shaver. I wanted to mention that I tried it with \\"Lectric Shave\\" liquid instead of shaving cream. While Lectric Shave was designed for electric shavers, I have to say that I still prefer shaving cream instead. After using Lectric Shave, there was a lot more stubble left, and I had some nicks on my face and razor burn. Shaving cream is a lot better. But Lectric Shave is about 50% better than shaving dry. When you use shaving cream, use it like the manual says: First wet your face with water, then apply shaving cream, then wet your shaver with water, then shave (in that order)... And as for my main review, I still really like the shaver and highly recommend it.

  194. I have used electric razors for many years and one of my main compaints over the years is the fact that it's often difficult to get a close shave with an electric razor. The Philips Norelco 1250x/40 SensoTouch provides the closest electric razor shave I have ever had and, as an added bonus, it lasts a long time between charges. I think the main advantage of the Norelco 1250 is the pivot head, which easily follows the curves of your face and allows the razor to get every last hair. The razor fits nicely in my hand and is easy to maneuver. Cleaning is easy. Just lift each individual head, run the razor under water and let it dry. At this point I am able to use the razor for two or three weeks before charging, which is a nice bonus. You also can use this razor wet or dry, which should please those who like to shave in the shower or prefer to use shaving cream or gel. The only way to charge the razor is through the stand (the jack for the charger is on the side of the stand). So, if you lose the stand, you lose your ability to charge the razor. Also, the razor heads cost about $70 to replace, which is not inexpensive. You can probably find replacement heads online for cheaper and, unless you have a heavy beard, my guess is you can probably replace the heads at longer intervals. Bottom line, this is a great electric razor. While a bit pricey, it does provide a very close shave and it's very easy and convenient to use.
  195. Searched high and low, read reviews on Amazon and elsewhere, and compared value and effectiveness. This thing shaves so much better than other electric razors, and does just as well of a job as my 3-blade standard razor. Couldn't be happier.

  199. I bought this shaver to replace another Norelco cordless razor (don't recall the exact model, but it used the almost as pricey HQ-9 heads) that I had misplaced en-route to recent deployment. That razor had served me faithfully for nearly 5 years, and I was only recently noticing the battery to not be lasting long. I figured, since the $100-something I spent on that razor lasted for 5 years, I'd drop the extra money on their newer, fancier line of razors. I was thrilled when I received it. The razor not only performed noticeably better than the crappy $8 electric razor I purchased while I was waiting for this razor, but also better than my old Norelco model with the HQ-9 heads. My face was noticeably smoother, and I was happy for the $150 or so that I paid for it so far. ...Then, after 4 months, my razor died, and no longer charged. I didn't have enough time remaining at my deployed location to go through the exchange process, so I waited until I got home. Once home, I contacted Norelco through their online customer support (around 17Oct2011). The Norelco CSR confirmed that my unit was bad, and offered a free replacement. I thought \\"Wow, that's it?\\" as my troubleshooting/replacement process only took a few minutes. Then came the waiting game. The next day, I received an email from Norelco advising me that my unit was back ordered, and there was no ETA for it. Weeks later, I received another email saying it would arrive 11Nov2011. Then, as that approached, yet another email, this time telling me that its back ordered until 22Nov2011. This waiting game has gotten quite irritating, as I've been using the aforementioned crappy $8 razor that does a sub-par job while I patiently wait Norelco to come through for me with my replacement razor. So far, my estimated time for a razor is about 1 month, in addition to the roughly 2 weeks that I was without it. If I were to purchase another razor again, at this point, I would skip this series, and go back to acordless model using the HQ-9 heads, which lasted me nearly 5 years (before I lost it), instead of 4 months, before dying. Norelco hasn't been too expedient at getting me a product that they actually make. It makes me wonder if they even sell it anymore, or are more interested in getting new razors to retailers, rather than returning customers, who's Norelco product has failed on them. Oh, and yes, the trimmer on it does suck. It slides out, but just barely. It's still functional, but not as much as ones that flip out..

  202. I've been using Norelco shavers for over 40 years and none of them compare to this. My only complaint, if you can call it one, is that it shaves so close that I need to use a lotion to soothe a slight razor burn.<br /><br />Its design is impressive and a complete departure from previous Norelco designs. It's light weight, easy to use and feels good in your hand. The trimmer works well and the clippings from the rotor blades don't empty into your hand or into the sink while trimming your sideburns like the previous model I had. It is over-packaged, but, thankfully, the polypropylene package was easy to open and recyclable.<br /><br />Overall, it's a vast improvement over previous models. Highly recommended.
