  206. I received the Senso Touch 3d for Christmas and I have to write that it is the best shave that I have ever experienced. I am 55 years old and have used a wide variety of electric shavers and blade shavers. Never have I had such a close shave with virtually no irritation. I dry shave so I clean it every two or three shaves. A hot water rinse of the heads only takes a minute. I quickly blow dry the blades with a hair dryer on low temperature. My wife is a hair stylist and she told me about the Wahl Total Clipper Care lubricant and cleaner which I use to lube the cutters after cleaning. The Wahl spray cleaner/lubricant is half the price of other cleaners such as Remington Shaver Saver and is available at Walmart. Lubricant reduces any heat build-up and should extend the life of the blades. I highly recommend this state-of-the-art Philips 3d shaver and although it is expensive, it is the best!
  207. I have used this shaver for several months now and nothing I have used during 60 years of shaving can compare with it. It doesn't bite, pull or irritate and it still gives a clean, quick shave. It is a breeze to clean, just rinse under hot water and blot it gently with a towel and set it out for a couple of hours to dry. I generally put it back in the charger after it dries so I can't really say how long it will go without charging. My beard is what I would describe as being moderately tough and I often go 2 to 3 days between shaves. It is very efficient at cutting this length. I try to follow Norelco's instructions to use a circular motion when shaving.
  208. Just received this as a replacement for a very old Braun 7 series. I wasn't aware that you couldn't just plug the cord into the razor as you can with ever other electric razor I have owned, you have to use a docking stand to charge the thing - inconvenient, over engineered and just plain stupid. One more thing to have to make sure you have when you travel, and the quality of the docking station material (light plastic) would seem to guarantee that it won't last as long as the razor.<br /><br />You will not power through any shave with this device, I have a light beard at best, and it took twice as long to get it knocked out as it does with a 13 year old Braun.<br /><br />I do have a few rogue hairs that come in very thick, the shaving head would just roll over these without cutting them, so I popped out the edge clipper, this exposed how weak the razor really is. You would think I was trying to cut copper wire by the sound it made every time the clipper hit a hair.<br /><br />Huge disappointment considering the reviews this razor received.
  209. Bought this for my partner's birthday and he absolutely loves it. He uses it with shaving foam when he wants an extra close shave and swears it works better than a razor. Can be used daily, though irritates a little until the skin gets used to it (after the first few weeks).
  210. Received SensorTouch 3D for Xmas gift. Really liked it overall. Negatives are that edge of blades don't allow for hairs close to nose area and pop-up trimmer works poorly. Have to use another razor for those areas. Main issue is that after 10 weeks, razor ceased working ... totally died. Called Customer Service. Very nice on phone but replacement handles are backordered without a projected date for manufacturing new ones. Therefore, I recommend holding off on a new purchase until production issues resolved. Serious backorder could indicate a manufacturing or design defect since there was no schedule for when handles will become available.
  211. 3/12/2011 - I had electrics (rotary and foil; Norelco and Braun) when I was a teen and transitioned to a blade over time due to lack of a close shave or too much irritation. I wanted to try an electric again and based on prior experience, purchased the Philips 1250x. It does take about two weeks of regular use to allow time for your face to adjust. During that time, you should expect a bit of neck rash and several missed hairs. Once your face adjusts, the 1250x does a fine job, though not as close as a blade, so 4 stars for the shaver but minus 1 star for the horrible trimmer. I have only used the razor with shave cream. Here are the pros and cons: Pros 1. Super quiet. 2. The 3D flex inward/outward blade head is cool and is responsible for the comfortable shave. This feature is why I chose the 3D model. 3. A very comfortable shave that previous electrics can't touch. The three primary differences between the 3D and less expensive 2D models is the 2D blades can't flex outward (they only flex inward), the 2D blades have a different shave pattern, and the 2D head must be popped off in order to attach the trimmer. Who knows, the 2D model may provide a better shave due to different blades and a pop off trimmer. 4. Made in the Netherlands (take that Made in Germany Braun). 5. LiPo recharge battery lasts a long time and charges quickly. 6. The shaver does not get near as hot as a foil shaver. Cons 1. The 1250x trimmer is one step above useless. I almost immediately returned the 1250x due to the absolutely horrible trimmer. The owners manual states the trimmer is a patented tube design. News flash, no one will steal your patent, Philips, because it is underpowered, too narrow, and ineffective. Be prepared to have a disposable just to shape and clean up your sideburns. Absolutely ridiculous at this price point. 2. The 1250x does not shave as close as a blade. **UPDATE** 5/15/2011 - Still love this razor. I traveled overseas for two weeks and did not take the charger. Had just enough juice to carry through but Philips needs to boost the battery a bit because it was a close call; otherwise, Philips should have kept the sturdy travel case with built-in charger that came with last year's Arcitec. The built-in trimmer is still absolutely useless. A complete waste of space and effort. Keep a cheap disposable razor handy to touch up your sideburns. The shave is still pretty close but not as close as a blade and it never will be, but it's a good shave and very comfortable. I've gotten used to the blades and there is zero burn or neck rash...there's something to be said about Philips' suggestion to give the razor 30 days so that your beard can adjust. Buy it...you'll love it for the shave and rue the day you met the built-in trimmer.
  212. Razor burn is going away now that I am using this razor. Closest shave I've gotten with an electric razor
  213. went and got the whole dame set!! My son loves it!! He's a Marine!!
  214. I cannot believe the difference in this shaver and the $70-90 shaver's I 've owed in the past. I am really upset I waited this long to spend the money on a topshelf shaver....its was well worth the extra money.
  215. Based on reviews, I recently bought the Braun series 3 and tried if for 4 weeks. I do not understand what people like about this razor. I found it not to give a close shave and it had a difficult time with longer stubble that you may have after a weekend of not shaving. It is possible that my beard growth is tougher than average, but in contrast the Norelco 1250x has worked great. It has been doing everything well, under the nose, on the chin, and even long stubble seem to cut just fine. I am surprised at how close the shave was based on the reviews I have read on these pages. It doesn't have the fancy cleaner like the Braun (which is kind of loud in the morning when my wife is trying to sleep), but hot water seems to work well at cleaning and is definitely cheaper than buying replacement cleaning solution. The trimmer is kind of lame, but I have a separate razor for that so it was not a big deal. I must admit the heads are kind of funky on the Norelco, so I am concerned how it will travel, but as far as the shave it is quite a bit closer than the Braun.

  221. I purchased this razor a year ago to replace a Norelco 8020X which I loved. The reason I was looking for a replacement was that the shaver heads for the 8020X were now costing as much as a new razor. I decided on the model 1250X. This razor was much bigger and bulkier than the 8020X but I gave it a chance. It did a good job shaving so I kept it. It came time to replace the shaver head, you don't just replace the blades on these, and I came to Amazon to shop. The original shaver head RQ12 had been replaced by RQ12+. I purchased it and was not very happy. The new head is not as flexible as the old one and is very obviously much cheaply made. I gave it three shaves and was still very unhappy with it. I contacted Philips-Norelco and told them why I was unhappy with the replacement head. They verified that it was the newer model of the original head and that there was really not much else they could do. They suggest I try a different razor since different models had different types of shaving heads. I decided that since it's going to cost me the price of a new razor to get a new shaver head that I would find a replacement head for my old 8020X.

  226. NOTE: I got this razor at Walmart for $80+tax because it was on super clearance for some reason so I gave it 5 stars. Otherwise, it would be only 4 because it is expensive and so are the replacement heads apparently! I have only used it twice so far and I am amazed at the quality of the shave. I have an uncooperative beard as it grows in, in different directions and I have problems with razor burn and ingrown hairs on my neck even after manual exfoliating after shaving. I usually shave with a safety razor and shaving cream. Then I have to exfoliate. I tried a medium end Braun and it took FOREVER to shave my face. I tried this shaver without shaving cream and it felt 99% as close as a safety razor. I also have almost no razor burn and don't have to exfoliate if I don't want to. The first time I tried it,it shaved off 4 days of stubble with absolutely no problem. The charging stand is rather flimsy (looks like it was designed by an artist instead of an engineer) but it gets the job done. If you can afford it, I would strongly suggest this shaver.
  227. Let me start off by saying I really wanted to like this razor. The razor is the nicest looking razor on the market. At $150 its also one of the most expensive. I usually use foil razors but I thought I would give this a chance since it's from a great company like Phillips. The razor provided a smooth shave but I found the foil razors provide a slightly easier shaving experience. The ease of cleaning was good as well. Here's the downside, this razor doesn't have the cutting power of others on the market. You'll get a closer shave with a Braun or a Panasonic. This razor also tore up the bottom of my neck whereas a razor like a Pansonic won't do that. If you have a thick beard this razor will not work for you. If you have light facial hair or plan on using this razor a few days out of the week you're in business.

  229. It is a pleasure to shave with this razor. It is so quite and smooth you hardly know you are shaving.   230. AWESOME money well spent
  231. After using a [[ASIN:B000G1785S Braun Series 5 (8985) Men's Shaver]] for about 2 yrs,I used this Philips Norelco and have been using for about past 8 months.<br />Overall, both of them provide a good shave, and if you are debating which one to go for, following may help:<br /><br />Similarities:<br /><br />Both electric shavers will give you a smooth shave and not necessarily a close shave. If your beard hair are very thick (and dark colored too), then you may observe slight blackish tinge on your beard line over time. This is due to the thick roots which will be left by either of these shavers. Only traditional shavers can provide you a very close shave in that case.<br /><br />Both are convenient to use, light-weight, and once fully charged, can easily go through a work week (assuming that you shave once a day only)<br /><br />Replacement blade heads cost almost same for both, about thirty-five dollars or so.<br /><br />Blades have a pretty long life. The manufacturers ask you to replace in 18 months but they go well over two years sometimes. However, this is also dependent on your beard thickness and density.<br /><br />Differences:<br /><br />Braun works well on face, and chin. It has to be maneuvered around on the neck in order to properly shave that area.<br />Norelco is awesome on face and neck, but can cause issues with the chin area. In either case, you get used to it in a few days.<br /><br />Norelco looks more stylish while standing on its base on the sink counter.<br />Braun looks a bit big due to the its base with the cleaning solution inside.<br /><br />Norelco's trimmer is more ergonomic and easier to use on sides.<br />Braun's trimmer is a bit oddly placed, since the shaver itself blocks your view while trimming sides...sort of a bad design example.<br /><br />Norelco has to be cleaned with warm water after every use, while Braun can be just put back into its base and the system itself will take care of the cleaning.<br />Braun's base is smart enough to figure out the level of cleaning needed. It has three levels, light, medium, and intense.<br /><br />Due to the cleaning solution, Braun shaver has bit higher operational cost, but extra convenience in use. You can buy a set of 2 pack cleaning solution for about ten-eleven dollars.<br /><br />Braun also comes with a neat form fit plastic case and a cleaning brush, thus, making it an ideal travel mate for business trips. The charger can also be connected directly to the shaver without the need of the base.<br />Norelco will always need its base in order to keep charged.<br /><br />Recommendation:<br /><br />If convenience, ease-of-carrying, and portability are your critical factors, then go with Braun.<br />If cost is your main factor, go with Norelco.Due to the cleaning solution, Braun shaver has bit higher operational cost, but extra convenience in use. You can buy a set of 2 pack cleaning solution for about ten-eleven dollars. Braun also comes with a neat form fit plastic case and a cleaning brush, thus, making it an ideal travel mate for business trips. The charger can also be connected directly to the shaver without the need of the base. Norelco will always need its base in order to keep charged. Recommendation: If convenience, ease-of-carrying, and portability are your critical factors, then go with Braun. If cost is your main factor, go with Norelco.

  234. While I was initially deterred by the price of this shaver the reviews persuaded my to purchase one. I have used the high end norelco shavers for 20 years and this one is the best product they have created to date. I can shave my entire face and neck in 45 seconds and get the best shave I have ever had. Prior products consistently left stubble in the hard to get places even when I shaved them several times. This product gets the stubble on the first pass. The flex head and design is comfortable to hold and easily accesses all the hard to get places on my face. While the trimmer is noisy compared to prior models, it's smaller design seems more efficient and effect that earlier models. I would give this shaver an A+ rating. Considering that i shave 365 days a year, a shave of this quality becomes a bargain at the price.

  239. Had Norelco razors for many years and decided to try a foil electric a couple of years ago. I bought a top of the line model but was never happy with the shave. After exhausting the special proprietary cleaning fluid canisters I bought with the razor, I got fed up and bought this razor. What a relief. At first it was so quiet I wondered if it was fully working but after my first shave I was really impressed. No irritation and the heads really do adapt to the contours of my face. I've never used an electric razor with a shaving cream but this razor is capable and the experience was terrific. It didn't feel like I was cutting anything, but the shave was incredibly close and ultimately smooth. I really love this razor and actually look forward to shaving. I never thought I would say that.
  240. First off, a disclaimer. My face is not your face. What works well for me may not work well for you. Both Norelco and Braun offer money back trial periods, so my main advice is to not overthink the decision or put too much stock in reviews like this one. I bought this shaver to replace a 2 year old Braun Series 3, which compared to the newer series 7 has the same foils and a slightly different \\"trim\\" middle blade on the head. So it's very similar. The trimmer stopped working, the cleaning base stopped charging it, and it was time for a new head. So I decided it was time for a new shaver. My previous Braun did a great job on my face, but it really struggled with my neck. It provided a very close shave but also missed a lot of whiskers, so it took a long time and a lot of going back and forth and stretching and pinching of my skin to get everything. In comparison, the SensoTouch 3D is much faster and misses a lot fewer hairs. I'd estimate it cuts my shaving time by about 1/3 to 1/2, also slighty faster than a blade. It's much better at getting stray longer hairs in areas I don't always pay attention to than the Braun, although it still can leave some. Usually if I go over stray hairs a few times this Norelco will get them, where with the Braun I'd have to break out the manual razor to touch up. It's also much quieter and easier to clean. The downside to the Norelco is that it just isn't as close a shave as the Braun and is a bit harsher on my face. Which is surprising since it requires so much less pressure than the Braun did. It's close, just not as close. Like another reviewer mentions, I also find it closer than a Gillette Fusion used with the grain. A manual razor against the grain will provide the closest shave, but also the most discomfort. The constant nicks, cuts, and mess of doing that is what keeps me coming back to electrics. Overall, I prefer this shave to anything else due to the consistancy, speed, and convenience. It literally takes about 20 seconds to clean this after each shave. This shaver is even easier to clean than my old Braun which had a noisy cleaning system because even using that you still had to periodically clean it manually. The Norelco also doesn't spill as many clippings while you are shaving, but still can spill some. I shave every day, and a charge lasts me over two weeks. The trimmer is best described as adequate. It works, but is probably the weakest of any electric shaver I have owned. If you do a lot of trimming, you'll probably want a seperate trimmer. So if this is the best overall shaver I have used, why just 3 stars? 2 things, price and portability. I don't want or need a wet shave, but Norelco does not give me a choice if I want these heads. Putting these heads on a lesser dry shaver would probably cut the cost in half. Also this shaver has an awkward large shape that does not travel as well as a Braun or lesser Norelco, and because of the wet shave ability there is no travel charger. If you need to charge it, you must bring the also awkwardly large stand. With the long run time this isn't a big issue for me, at least not with new strong batteries. In a couple years it may be. There is just nothing overly impressive about the build quality that I feel justifies the high price unless you must have the wet shave ability. But it is still the best shaver I have ever used, so I do recommend it.
  241. First use of this razor and I am very impressed and satisfied. I tried the 'dry' shave and had no irritation afterwards, which I always had after shaving with other razors. Very lightweight and gives a very smooth shave. The price is a little steep for a razor, but I think it will be well worth it. If you can afford it, buy this razor. You wont be disappointed.
  242. good shaver, highly recommend. my previous Philips had lack of power. this one is solid, powerful and accurate. if you want to shave electric this seems to be the way to go (this is the 3rd saver i buy in the last 3 years and only now i am satisfied).

  251. I've always been a fan of Norelco products and this electric razor does not disappoint. The sleek style had me thinking this razor would be mostly form over function but I was wrong. The design is intelligent and the pivoting heads provide a smooth and comfortable experience. An added bonus is the ability to shave wet and dry. Each head also clicks up/open for easy cleaning under the faucet. The razor is a bit pricey but it's refreshing to see quality craftsmanship. I'm glad I opted for the \\"bare-bones\\" model as my counter space is sparce and I'm really not sure how much better it can get. Also, the extra cost didn't appear justifiable. UPDATE 10/28/11 After using this razor for several months, it does offer an amazing shave. The only issue that I have found is that the heads are pretty small and thus can only hold a small amount of trimmed hair. It's not a big deal but most standard 3 head electric razors have a large cavity below the cutting heads that can hold ample trimmings. This razor must be cleaned more often. This is likely Norelco's reason for offering a cleaning system. Not a big enough problem to downgrade my rating but something to consider when purchasing. (I've read the cleaning system can be quite cumbersome so I'm still very happy with my decision to buy the \\"bare-bones\\" model.
  252. I very rarely give reviews on products unless they leave a great impression on me. I've been using safety razors for 4+ years since I have a very thick beard, and safety razors were the only way for me to get a close shave. I decided to give electrics another try (last time was ~10 years ago At first I thought I wasted my money, but after about a month of my face getting accustomed to the shaver - I absolutely love it now! I can shave in about the same amount of time as with my safety razor with the same amount of closeness. I am now able to shave on the go, and I no longer have the shaving irritation as I had before. I would buy this razor again in a heart beat, knowing what I know now. If you are on the fence because you have a thick beard and don't believe this product will work, give it a try! You won't regret it.
  253. Great shaves! I've used Norelcos for 30+ years, and 1259x/40 is another improvement in shave quality. That said, Philips has lost its way with maintenance: (1) Instructions for cleaning the shaving unit are for rinsing the razor heads closed under hot water \\"for a few minutes\\" followed by rinsing under hot water open \\"for at least 30 seconds.\\" That cleaning takes longer than shaving and uses as much hot water than shaving with a blade. (2) The razor has a drain duct from the heads down to a little hole the bottom of the razor. (Really!) The instructions say, \\"While rinsing razor heads, water may drip out of the base of razor. This is a normal occurrence.\\" Truth is, it drains out slowly, over hours, and will drip out after taken off its stand for your next shave. If you happen to be sitting down while shaving, it will drip on you. (Really!) --Not house broken. I can hardly believe it. Maybe you should buy this shaver for this hee ha value... (3) The RQ12 (replacement) razor heads are good but pricey. If I continue to use this excellent shaver for 6 years and replace the heads annually, I will have paid twice the purchase price of the shaver for replacement heads. --I do not much like the increasingly common approach of pricing maintenance items to make the profit for the product.
  254. I have been using Philips for long time, which I was always happy with philips product. But this is the first time with 3D electric, which is great - very close to skin. loved it.
  255. As far as electric shavers are concerned this one does rank high. I have had Remington and Braun shavers and I think this one is better. The Norelco is still not as good as a regular blade razor.
  256. Since there are already many detailed reviews, this one will focus on performance and value. I have a light beard so I've only used electric, and I'm a Norelco guy. My previous Norelco was of the standard $40-$70 variety, and gave me 15 years of reliable service before getting noisy, sputtering, and generally being ready to conk out. Is it worth paying 2-3 times as much for a SensoTouch 3D? Here's my take.<br /><br />Performance:<br /><br />It takes about an hour to be fully charged. After two weeks of use, the indicator shows it still has more than a third of its power left, so no nuisance there. I always dry shave, and doing so with the 3D works very well. I definitely get a closer shave than with the old model. It took a few shaves to get used to the heads being placed further apart than with a standard Norelco (so they have room to pivot), so there's more need to use a circular motion. The 3D is amazingly quiet, as opposed to the very unpleasant screeching of the old one echoing in my small bathroom. Far and away the best part of the experience is the ability to easily shave my neck, which gets as full a beard as my face. This is where the 3D heads shine. No awkward angles as I aim for curved areas, and no going over the same area until I have razor burn. My jaw line finally gets a clean shave on one or two passes, especially the area just behind the sides of my jaw that was terrible to aim at before.<br /><br />Value vs. a cheaper shaver:<br /><br />Why spend so much on this product? Because it gives a closer, more comfortable shave, is faster since you won't have to go back to tackle missed hairs or stubble in hard to reach spots, and it's so easy to clean. No more removing the head, unclasping a holder, taking the blades out, then brushing it out. An indicator tells you when to rinse it out. Ten seconds under the tap and it's clean. The three blade chambers open easily but click firmly back in place every time.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br /><br />Having gotten by with a lesser shaver for years, I'd say this is somewhat of a luxury item. As someone who can afford better (yet is pretty thrifty), the SensoTouch 3D does everything I hoped it would and I'm very glad I spent the extra money. If you can afford one, it's definitely a good investment. If it's as durable as my last Norelco, I won't need another one until 2027!
  257. I used the \\"old style\\" Norelco for years. I also tried two other brands from time to time, always returning to the Norelco brand. Before this Senso Touch I used a Br.... for 18 months, until the trimmer fell of. It was replaced quickly at no cost, but in the mean time I purchased the Senso Touch. I now use the Br... at my vacation home and the SensoTouch at home therefor I can compare the the two. The SencoTouch is, by far, the best shaver I have used. It's faster, causes less irritation and shaves closer than any of my previous shavers. The only two things that I can criticize about the SensoTouch is the high cost of the replacement heads and the trimmer placement. The trimmer placement makes it hard to see what you are trimming.

  263. Received this as an anniversary gift from my wife and this was the best close shave I ever got in my life. Its great for dry but i really do enjoy the wet shave as it gives a very close shave.<br />The first shave is always tricky since you have to follow a circular motion along the contours of the face. Once you are comfortable with the pattern you get the best smooth close shave feeling.<br /><br />I have thick hair so I use the shaving foam to get a comfortable shave. I did try the dry shave option but owing to the hair thickness left me irritate for a while.<br /><br />I foam the face twice. Once for the regular shave and the second round for doing the getting around the remaining hair that was left behind. If you are using a shaving foam I would recommend running the blade under the faucet after a couple of strokes just like the regular razor blade.<br /><br />Remember to move in a circular fashion against the grain of your beard and try to stretch you neck against the direction you are shaving while shaving the neck hair.<br /><br />You might wonder that replacement blade is expensive around $50 on amazon but I have been using for 5 months and so far I have saved $20 on gillettes .
  264. I have, what was considered at the time, a high end Norelco razor (9160xl) which was in need of new heads (I replace about every 18 months). The 9160 is 5 years old. The battery life was OK, but was down to needing a charge every two weeks. It shaves fine, just not fantastic, and the one nit I have is that if I go 3 days without shaving, it tugs and pulls vs lifts and cuts in spots. I also have the luxury of a 15 year old in need of a razor, without the same \\"refined\\" criteria that I have. I have another son, who was shaving with a very old speed xl razor that has no battery life left. I needed at least two razors, so did considerable research based on the following criteria: Shaver 1: Need a good trimmer to allow a quick, but not perfect shave similar to a 5 o'clock shadow Has to minimize razor burn and rash on the neck area, but has to get pesky sideways neck hair and the angles without a lot of work Can't shave too low - few spots prone to ingrown hairs when hair is yanked out or cut too low below the skin Want a shave that is relatively close, and doesn't take lots of additional clean up for missed areas Shaver 2: 23 yr old son is prone to razor bumps - need to be able to minimize that Has to be able to handle thick, tough beard and shave relatively close Trimmer for sideburns and/or beard depending on his style of the week And finally, something good enough to keep him from using razor number one... I did significant research really trying to find something better than a Norelco. I have had 3 and while all were good, was willing to look at much higher price if the performance was right. Panasonic was not seriously considered, especially since I prefer a quick, dry shave, but I looked at it for my son. Did not appear it was going to handle the razor bumps well, and may tap his patience when shaving wet. Braun was next. I really wanted to like the razor. My research suggested it was a little more prone to complaints of razor burn, and it was not quite as good in the hard to reach areas of the neck. It also does not appear to be good for razor bumps. I checked out the Wahl offerings that are supposed to be much better for bumps, but decided not to go that route. There were issues with quality that came up. I was stuck taking a risk on the Norelco 3D for Razor number 1. Managed to find it for $159 with a $30 rebate just before Christmas, so could not pass on the great deal. I used it for the first time on the 26th - and promptly bought another one for my son, whose birthday was 2 days later (thanks Amazon Prime for the one day shipping rate). There are a few differences between the old speed and smart touch xl razors compared to the 3D. The heads - ultra cut and dual precision - the screen has a different design. Yes it has triple cut action, but the inner and middle circles are very different, and it appears to make a huge difference in the shave. It is much smoother. I have tried to get this razor to tug after 3-4 days growth, but it just cuts right thru smooth and easy. My 9160 had a good independent head system, but the 3d gyro is better. Much more flexible and gets to all the places on my neck with relative ease. I do not have to go over and over areas and contort to get a good shave. Nor do I have to spend time tracking down stragglers. The trimmer is significantly smaller than any of the prior models. However, it does a much better job. It takes a few more strokes to cover the same area, but what it cuts, it cuts much closer and better than the other models. In talking with my son, he cannot believe the shave he gets. His tough beard is shaved smooth, and more importantly, he has not had an issue with rash or razor bumps in 3 weeks. I know my wife is tired of hearing from both of us how much we like our new razors, but we are still amazed at how much better the shaves are than what we thought was possible. Find a deal, it is worth every penny.
  265. My husband loves the razor. He is very pleased with how close it shaves wet or dry. Would recommend to anyone.

  270. I have been using this shaver daily for about 6 months and it has yet to disappoint me. The first month of use was somewhat frustrating as you have to \\"train\\" your hairs to use an electric shaver versus a regular razor. During this period you will have to go over the same spot several times, and even then there will be patches that will get missed, and require you to go over with a manual shaver. After this \\"training\\" period it works very well. There are still a few times if I do not shave in a day or two and have longer hairs that I will have patches that do not get cut. I have found that using this as a wet shaver (which is a nice feature) works better for me than it does as a dry shaver. This keeps the hairs from falling out of the shaver as some have complained about. To me this is a design feature that is both convenient and inconvenient. It will not hold the hairs in the head, which will keep it from clogging up and extends the life of the razor. On the flip side, this can cause a bit of a mess. It's a bit of a trade off to me, and is why I prefer using it as a wet shaver. The stand is a bit unbalanced, but does not take up a lot of real estate on your counter top either. Again, this is a trade off. The carrying case is a nice bonus, however if you are going on an extended trip, it is a hassle to have to take the base along with you (but at least it will not take up too much room in your luggage). Overall I have found this to be a good product. It is not perfect, but sometimes you can't have your cake and eat it too.

DOA.. nothing.. won't turn on.. ok, i meter the charger and its producing about 16 VDC as required..<br />so i telephoned the philips customer support telephone number and after a few questions the person tells me that i should NOT leave it in the charger when i am not using it..! HUH..!? leaving it in the charger, she says, will destroy the battery.. HUH again..?! BUT the lady is kind enough to say she will ship a replacement out (7 to 10 days) from someplace in ohio and that when i get it i need to return the dead \\"handle\\"..<br /><br />SO, i suppose the point here is this thing about the battery not being able to take being in the charger.. i guess i'm supposed to lay it on its side and only charge it when it needs it..? Come ON philips/Norelco, smart battery charging technology is all OVER the place.. for this expensive razor they can at least have a smart charger that stops charging when the battery is fully charged..<br /><br />SO, i await the replacement (7 to 10 business days) with a fuzzy face or a torn up face (from using the braun).. seven to ten days.. UPS ground from ohiop should take no more than 3 days MAX..<br /><br />I will add here that a funny thing happened on the way to bed monday night.. my philips sonicare toothbrush (about 6 months old) followed the razor into failure mode but this charger is not stupid, its smart and the toothbrush still runs but does not vibrate.. philips seems to have good customer care (same story about a replacement as the razor, 7 to 10 business days!) but at least there is no aggument.. this time i bought a spare sonicare toothbrush.. you know the old line about the \\"heir and a spare\\".. :-)<br /><br />EDIT: (may 28, 2014) Hello Philips..? yes, your razor has died again..! whats that..? you say its out of warranty..?! oh.. Damn..<br />so, now what, dead razor and i really need to shave.. well, out comes that old braun shaver and WOW, it still holds a charge and still works..<br />after a half hour on the telephone with American Express who give an additional year of warranty on anything purchased WITH your Amex card they (amex) says they'll consider the claim and let me know in a day or so..<br />so, off i go to this amazon site again and buy another philips razor (prime will get it to me wednesday) and i'll wait to see if amex credits my card account with the cost of the last flaky philips triple wammy superdooper self cleaning razor (again, i must be a masochist!)..<br />the only good thing about these philips-norelco razors is they give a really excellent shave..<br />so, dear prospective customers, its up to you whether you want to rely on an unreliable razor (and toothbrush) that is, well, unreliable or opt for some other brand that might be MORE reliable.. you pay your money and you take your chances..<br />for myself, i will keep my old reliable braun self cleaning razor for that time the philips norelco razor craps out and given its history, it will do so with sad regularity..

  279. I bought the Braun 790cc thinking it was the best on the market. You see, I've used blades for years but hate the amount of time it adds to my morning grooming. So my search for the best electric razor began. After getting the braun home I was in love with its build quality. You would think this was made by Apple it is so sturdy. Unfortunately, after my first shave with my new shiny razor I wasn't too impressed. The cheeks and mandible was acceptable but my neck was really not good at all. After a week of shaving I had got better with controlling the razor but shaving took quite a while and I would need to make several passes to get all the stubble, and still there was some left on my neck that I would quickly clean up with my fusion proglide. Just for kicks I went out and bought the Norelco sensotouch 3d to compare and the results are interesting. First, the sensotouch is much easier to shave with since it conforms to your face as you move it from one part to the next and it takes fewer passes through the same area to get a clean shave thus greatly reducing the amount of time it takes to shave. (Quite honestly, I spend at most 1/2 the time shaving with the sensotouch as with the series 7) It doesn't shave as comfortably as the series 7 but I would hardly say it was uncomfortable and I experienced no irritation or redness. I really wanted to love the series 7, thats why I bought it first; but in the end, for the money, the Norelco sensotouch 3d does win out. The shave was just as close if not closer, easier, quieter, and faster. Thanks Norelco

  288. Like a lot of guys, I was at first hesitant to move from blades to electric, but was looking for better solution than scraping my face with sharp steel every day, so eventually decided to \\"try\\" an electric face mower.<br /><br />That was perhaps 10 years ago, and since then I have owned several Braun and Remington varieties. When it came time to replace my latest Lawnboy, I decided to take a closer look at the higher end offerings. I was hoping to get something that provided a smoother, more comfortable shave. Efficiency, ergonomics and any bells / whistles would be nice benefits.<br /><br />It was tough making the leap to the higher price points, but the reviews strongly favored going for something like this Norelco, so I pulled the trigger and purchased the 1250X from Amazon. In the worst case - I figured - If it didn't live up, I could simply return it and get another $50 something or other.<br /><br />When I got the Norelco, I charged it up and the next day took it for its first test drive. WOW, what a pleasant surprise and experience. It was like the first time behind the wheel of a well crafted sorts car after spending a lifetime driving cheap sedans.<br /><br />The unit is very comfortable in the hand, light and easy to maneuver. Most importantly, the shave is close, fast and remarkably smooth. With this Norelco, there isn't the tugging and pulling that's typical of the lower priced models (even when they are new).<br /><br />What's more, there is virtually no irritation. For those who have used other models, you know that it typically takes several passes to get the shave you want. Not so here. Even the difficult areas are clean with just a couple of passes.<br /><br />No need for earplugs. For those of you accustomed to the jet engine roar of other models, you may enjoy getting fooled into thinking that the battery charge on this Norelco was dying, like I've been several times.<br /><br />Hey, we guys have to struggle with shaving nearly every day - don't skimp out. Super quiet, a surprisingly smooth, close shave, comfortable and efficient, this product is true winner and well worth the extra dollars to own it. I wish I'd gotten one a lot sooner.risingly smooth, close shave, comfortable and efficient, this product is true winner and well worth the extra dollars to own it. I wish I'd gotten one a lot sooner.
  289. I love reading product reviews. A few of them are really helpful, many of them are just amusing. If you want an electric shaver that gives an extremely comfortable, close shave, this is the one. I'm not going to get into the discussion about electric versus blades; I've given enough blood in my time, thank you very much. I have used an electric razor exclusively for many years, and have tried many. This Norelco is the best I have ever used. Some reviewers complained that you have to clean the razor too frequently. You can either brush out the shaving chambers or rinse them under water. This takes about 30 seconds. If you want a shaver that you have to clean less frequently, but that gives an inferior shave, there are plenty of them on the market. Many reviewers complained about the trimmer. I wonder exactly what they are expecting to do with the trimmer on an electric razor. The trimmer will even up your sideburns and trim the bottom edge of a mustache. I doubt very much that it was ever intended to replace a beard and mustache trimmer, which is a completely different grooming tool. And I love the way the trimmer slides out with the push of a lever. Some of the older Norelco razors had a spring-loaded trimmer that could pop up at inappropriate times if you touched the release just right. I think this one is a big improvement in that regard.
  290. Mistake to have gotten, the replacement blades I would give a -5 if it were available. They pull do not cut well and make you want to go back to shaving cream and razor

  293. I had a 10 year old Norelco (6705x), which was pretty decent in and of itself. I was pleasantly surprised to start shaving with this new Norelco.<br />- I have sensitive skin and it irritates easily, that's the reason I moved to electric shavers in the first place. This Norelco is smoother and easier on the skin than the previous version I had (10 years old). To put a number, I think it's about 30-40% better in this regard.<br />- I think it's about the same in closeness - I have generally found electric shavers to offer closer shaves than regular blades, but that may be just dependent on how I use electric blades.<br />- It offers better coverage. Previously, there would small (very small) patches of areas that would remain unshaven and I would have give some final touches with a blade. That's much less the case with the new shaver.<br />- Love the in-build trimmer.<br />- Battery live is pretty good - you can probably get 10+ shaves in before having to re-charge.
  294. I own this electric razor, but was a die-hard fan of blade shaving most of my life. Blade-shaving still gives the best shave, in my opinion. However, there's a lot to be said for not having to use shaving cream, and being in a hurry, and not having to worry about cutting yourself.<br /><br />My first 9 months with this electric were frustrating. The shave was not nearly as good as a blade -- and if I missed two days without shaving it seemed to NEVER really get rid of the growth.<br /><br />And one day, it occurred to me to try a different technique. With a blade razor, you get used to making straight strokes -- whether up or down, or sideways. Always straight strokes. The first instinct with this electric is to do the same thing. But it doesn't really work for me. You think \\"Well, all three heads are rotating, so there's no need to do anything else... right?\\"<br /><br />Then I tried moving the shaver in small circles while using it -- and it made all the difference in the world! For whatever reason, it works great using this technique. It does a closer and faster shave. You should try it.<br /><br />This might be nmentioned in the Owner's Manual -- but who has time to read THOSE? 8-)<br /><br />The 4 Stars are only because this will never be as close as a blade razor. But it'll do!
  295. This shaver is excellent. It delivers a close shave, is very quiet and best of all was about half the price that I would have to pay for the same product in New Zealand.
  296. This all black model has the nicest, cleanest aesthetic of all the Norelco higher end models. So many of their models have two toned designs that just look cheap. The shaver works fine, but no better, faster, or closer than the 8 year old $40 dollar model that it replaced. I'm not sure why these higher end models cost so much. There are also a few flaws with this model that are annoying when shaving. First, the surface around the heads extends out farther than on the cheaper models which means that you can't get the blades to cut as close to your nose and ears. Second, the width of the slide up trimmer is narrower than on the older and cheaper models, which makes sideburns harder to trim straight, Third, the ergonomics of the long pointy handle feels awkward. I prefer the shape of the smaller rounder Norelcos, even though I have large hands. Fourth, the instructions states that your beard will adapt to the heads over 21 days which will lead to a closer shave. I have not noticed any improvement. It was reasonably close from the start and has remained so for me. Shaving time started out a bit slow and remained so..<br /><br />Others have complained about the flimsy charging stand. It's not really as bad as I thought it would be. I just wish the cord wasn't so springy. It makes it hard to pack in a travel case. You have to bring the stand when you travel. You can't plug the cord directly into shaver as with the older models. This is a real drag.<br /><br />I really wanted to like this shaver. I still do from the standpoint of it's aesthetics, but the shaving experience is a let down. I wish Norelco would do a major redesign on the functional aspects.
  297. Purchased phillips norelco before heading to Afghanistan for the second time the razor has held up through the entire deployment and still works great to this day!
  298. Excellent razor. Best and easiest shave I have had from an electric razor
  299. Dont buy this or any Norelco shaver. Unless you see sense in spending more for future replacement heads than you did for the shaver.
  300. My wife got this for me for Christmas and it does a great job. The only issue that I had came when I tried to get replacement blades. They cost nearly $200. I will be shopping for different razor with affordable replacement blades.
  301. Your comment is awaiting moderation.<br /><br />No matter how good the 12xx series Norelco's are, they are useless if they don't work. Here's the problem with these shavers. The charging stand was designed by an idiot. And, the razor cannot be charged without the stand.<br /><br />Due to a massive imbalance when sitting on the stand, the stand uses 3 suction cups to hold it to whatever (very smooth) surface it's sitting on. Surrounding the suction cups are three moulded in plastic tabs that do a superb job of preventing the cups from adhering to anything. The shaver is held on the stand by two weak magnets that barely can hold it in place on a completely level surface let alone take even the slightest brush of a hand or towel passing by. The wiz kids at Philips need to take physics 101 and learn a bit more about something called gravity.<br /><br />More; the stand is really flimsy. If you plan on traveling with it, protect it well. With no protection, the stand is about the same envelope as the shaver and, yet another part, the charger combined. If that's not acceptable, understand you can't charge this shaver without it's stand. If it is acceptable, protect the stand well as it's delicate, bulky and required.<br /><br />Norelco did do a fine job of designing the stand in a manner that the shaver will slide through a hole in the bottom of the stand and be cradled very nicely. However, now it won't fit in it's pouch nor make contact with the charging nubs. I have no idea why this was done.<br /><br />I bought the 1250x. The first two times I charged it on a perfectly level granite counter, it fell off. It was returned.<br /><br />There are three reasons not to buy this product. 1), the stand is very poorly designed to the point of being useless. 2), the battery life is almost half what older Norelco's were. 3), any company who displays the design incompetence embodied in the stand does not merit anyone's business.<br /><br />I never used the shaver, it was returned before I could get a charge on it.<br /><br />Suggestion Philips, look at an iPhone. They are not that rare and you can probably find one in your employee pool. If you don't, it may say something about the people designing your products.efore I could get a charge on it.<br /><br />Suggestion Philips, look at an iPhone. They are not that rare and you can probably find one in your employee pool. If you don't, it may say something about the people designing your products.

  303. I've had a Braun shaver for about 3 yrs. The price of the cleaning refills was getting rediculous. I decided to go back to a rotary style and I am very happy I did. It took about 3 days for my face to acclimate to the change but once it did, I was very impressed. The shave is cleaner and quicker. The most amazing thing to me is the noise level, or better stated the lack of noise. You almost aren't sure if it is running at full speed but it is. Very easy to clean under the tap by flipping up the three heads, then shake the water out and put it on the charger. I looked at the cost of replacing the head on the Braun and the ongoing cost of cleaner cartidges and figured it would pay for itself in 9 - 11 months of use. The Braun was not a bad shaver, just nothing better to justify the ongoing costs.
  304. First I tried the Philips Norelco 8240 shaver when my old electric gave out, but couldn't stand how it pulled long stubble that had grown after the last shave a few days earlier. Very painful. Perhaps it would have been fine if I shaved every day with out fail, but there are always going to be times when I skip a day or two. I returned the 8240 under Philips generous 45-day return policy and bought the 1250x/40 despite the big price difference. I would not give it a perfect score on long stubble as it takes a while to get all the whiskers mowed down and still pulls a few, but it was far superior compared to any electric I've previously owned and left my face relatively irritation free. I would definitely say the 1250x is worth the price difference based on its ability to competently handle long stubble alone.

  308. UPDATE: My previous review is below, but i've since returned this product due to it's design flaws. Probably the most frustrating thing is the fact that you can't get through one, or maybe two, shaves before hair dust is spilling out all over your shirt. It seems to be due to the small compartments that hold the hair and the large slot openings in the blades. My old norelco didn't have this problem; if hair ever came out (rarely) it was because i'd gone over a week without emptying it, but at least it holds a weeks worth! My conclusion was that although the shave is great, it's not that much better than my old norelco, and the frustrations aren't worth the cost of this expensive shaver. This shaver is great! It's much better than the Braun Series 7 - 720S which I tried first but returned. The Norelco is a much closer shave and it gets odd hairs around the neck line with ease. It's very quiet and feels good on the face. The Pros: it meets all the claims it makes in the product description. The cons: the flip-up trimmer is not as good as older Norelco shavers; there are 3 seperate compartments that capture hair and it fills up quickly, requiring emptying about every day; my major complaint is that it requires use of the charging stand and does not plug in directly, which sucks for traveling.

  323. I am a previous die-hard \\"scraper razor\\" guy with a very heavy beard. I had tried some electric razors in the past with terrible results; usually significant razor burns and excess stubble.<br /><br />Over the last several months I seemed to have developed a skin allergy to the lubricating pad now found on most manual razors. It was getting to the point of considering a beard of which I am not a fan (for myself).<br /><br />I read about this razor and decided to give it a try. I have been using it about 6 weeks. I had read in some other reviews that you need to give your skin a few weeks to get used to a new way of shaving. I had some mild discomfort for the first two shaves and none since. I use it every day and it has been a delight and pleasure to use with no problems.<br /><br />It does not shave quite as close as a manual razor but way more than adequate. My wife says she cannot tell the difference. The difference to me is that my skin is no longer breaking out and painful. I never have a razor cut and it is very easy to use. Have tried both wet and dry but use dry about 90% of the time. It has been a great investment.

  325. This razor makes shaving a pleasure! I would recommend it whole heartedly to anyone one who needs a comfortable shave.
  326. This is an update of a review I wrote a few days ago. I've now had the shaver two weeks and am convinced there is nothing better available. If you shave against the grain with a blade, a light touch, and good beard prep, you may get closer, but at the cost of considerably more irritation. I have a $100 Panasonic foil-type razor, and there's no comparison between that and the Philips Norelco 3d. The Norelco bests it in every way except for the electronic display and battery life, which are superior on the Panasonic. But the Norelco gives a closer, more comfortable shave by far. I recommend shaving dry, not only for convenience, but it seems to result in a better shave. In three minutes you get a good shave; if you take added time, you can get a perfect shave. I find shaving relaxing, so if I'm not in a hurry, I'll just chill out and shave till I have a smooth, uniform shave. I'm still astonished by how well this thing shaves dry. The trick is to run it over the skin just firmly enough that there is no stretching or movement. Unlike with other electrics, there's no need to stretch the skin manually. Using circles, find the areas which still have stubble and use circles of different sizes and directions. You will feel it bite the stubble and remove it; I achieve better results without a mirror because I concentrate on the feel. It even does a good job with flat hairs lying on the neck, though extra caution is called for in this area. My skin is fairly sensitive, and any minor redness subsides in a few minutes with no additional treatment. It's easy to clean -- don't waste your money on the fancy cleaner. I'd like a display that tells me more clearly how much battery life is remaining, but perhaps the marketing department at Philips Norelco needed a way to disaggregate their product line and charge more on the high end. Such is life on the razor's edge. If you want an electric razor, just buy this thing. It rules.
  327. Shave is less close than older, standard model. This unit looks cool, the charging stand and battery life is great, it cleans easily. There is only one problem. It does not shave as close as the old traditional Speed XL type. Quite disappointed.

  329. First, the razor works well. I have been a Norelco user for about 15 years. They keep getting better. This one is better than either of the two other Norelco's I've had. Not only do I my face but I keep going and shave my head with the razor. It hardly feels like you're shaving. The charging stand sucks. I give it 1 star because it does charge the razor. I travel a lot and most times its for two weeks or more. What a pain to have to take the whole stand on a trip, especially when you want to pack light and not to pay for extra baggage charges. Every inch of space counts. The design engineers had their heads way up in the dark on this one. A simple U shaped cradle with a flat bottom that can sit flat on any surface would be better. Back to the razor, I thought the 3 separate heads would be a pain to clean, but I was wrong. It is actually easier to clean than any of my earlier Norelco razors. You just flip them open shake and rinse. Something I didn't used to do with my other razors because I thought what the heck there was a big holding area there so who needs to clean it every time. This one cleans in 10 seconds if that and just lay it down on the trimmer edge with the heads popped open and it dries in no time. My recommendation is BUY this razor and put up with the charger until they make a more compact or travel charger.
  330. I've traditionally been more of a regular Gillette Mach 3 Turbo kinda guy, but the idea of an electric razor has always appealed to me.<br /><br />As far as the quality, if I shave somewhat regularly, this razor does do a decent job, though it takes longer than traditional shaving as I do have to go over the same areas multiple times and that can leave your skin irritated.<br /><br />For precision trimming of areas like sideburns, there is a retractable electric razor on the backside that works well.<br /><br />The fact that this razor works on dry or wet skin is also a nice bonus. I'm not entirely convinced that the \\"3D\\" aspect and benefit of having razor heads that can move in three different directions is entirely beneficial, although it did make shaving around my chin a bit easier.<br /><br />This particular model is a great value. The more expensive model just features a different finish and LED on the front and an automated cleaning apparatus, which is a bit overkill when you can just run this razor under the faucet. Overall, this razor does a good job, but I won't be giving up my traditional Mach 3 anytime soon.
  331. In spite of the hype I would say this shaver shaves as well as or very slightly better than my old Norelco does with new cutters installed, certainly not enough better to justify the much higher price. For previous Norelco users there are a few surprises. To open the cutter heads for cleaning, the 3 heads open individually instead of all 3 at once. To charge the shaver it must be mounted in the stand. The power plug only plugs into the stand, it doesn't fit the shaver socket, that plugs into the stand. If you plan to travel, the stand and charger do not fit into the shaver case, you have to pack them separately. To see the charge level indicator, you have to look fast when you turn the shaver off, and not in a bright light.

This had the best ratings for a wet/dry razor, so I went with it.<br /><br />I've only shaved once with it so far, but it was very comfortable and far quieter than the Braun razor I used for many years, and gave me a nice close shave.
  359. I bought this for my boyfriend last Christmas after a particularly bad case of razor burn from one of his cheap, blunt disposable razors. He of course saw nothing wrong with this until he started using this electric razor. THE DIFFERENCE IS AMAZING. I had done a lot of research beforehand, and I know that electric razors normally don't get as close a shave as a manual one but I am not kidding you, this one does.<br /><br />This is well worth the money, my boyfriend LOVES it, uses it EVERYDAY and I have not seen any razor burn, bumps, nicks or cuts since he started using it. Just a silky smooth face. He says it is very comfortable to use, and the wet or dry function is pretty nifty too. It's also super easy to clean (i didnt buy the one with the jet stream cleaning system as 1. too expensive and 2. come on, it takes 2 seconds to manually clean it). Plus it looks pretty sleek and sexy too.<br /><br />From a purely functional point of view; you can depend on this razor to give you a brilliant, comfortable shave, every time. I guarantee it. As a daily-use razor it is definitely worth every single dollar!

  361. It doesn't tug when my scruff is long which is great. I love that it has an easy grip too.

  363. Bottom-Line: On balance I am very disappointed in the \\"SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver,\\" so much so that I think I'll be going back to the tried and true Advantage 7735X.<br /><br />Over the years I have tried a number of razors--any number of traditional one-to-four blade straight (disposable) handles, as well as electric units from Remington and Norelco. All of them irritate my skin to some degree and leave razor bumps (Black men are more susceptible to razor bumps than white men because of the course curly nature of our hair). Traditional razors tend to irritate my skin the most, and through experimentation over the years, I have found that Norelco brand razors tend to irritate my skin much less than all the others. So, I have stuck with Norelco for the past fifteen years or so.<br /><br />Recently, a \\"SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver,\\" by who else, Norelco fell into my hands and I put it to the test. Since I shave my head and face at least three times a week, it is important to me that any razor I use shave closely without, again, irritating my skin. After several weeks of use I have been very disappointed in the \\"SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver\\" performance; after I shave my scalp is often dry and somewhat flaky in need of lotion, but no shaving bumps so that is a great outcome.<br /><br />First Impressions<br /><br />Unlike the Advantage 7735X, which comes with 5 lotion packs by Nivea that are easy to insert into the back of the razor, the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver does not come so equipped. And that for me is the main disadvantage of the razor; while the Advantage 7735X shaves closely, without lotion, and even better with it, without some sort of moisturizer the \\"SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver\\" fails to shave as closely as I'd like.<br /><br />You can also use shaving cream with the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver, but that can get a bit messy (I only tried it once) and the shave was not much better and the reason I use an electric razor is so I do not have to use shaving gel!<br /><br />I like the design of the unit, it is cutting edge and stylish. The razor fits easily into the hand and while running the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver is quieter than the unit it replaces. The small collapsible trimmer in the back of the unit works well.<br /><br />The SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver is cordless and comes with a charging stand that can automatically switch to the prevailing voltage, so traveling overseas will not be an issue. It also comes with a carrying case large enough to hold everything that comes with the razor, including the charging base, and a small cleaning brush.<br /><br />I have owned three other Norelco razors, and the only one that shaves as close as the Advantage 7735X was the Advantage 5655. On balance I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver, so much so that I think I'll be going back to the tried and true Advantage 7735X, or perhaps try a new lotion pack model; the lotion packs agree with my skin.<br /><br />And the really good news for my fellow razor bump suffers: I have not had a single bump since I started shaving with the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver that at least is plus for the razor.electric razor is so I do not have to use shaving gel!<br /><br />I like the design of the unit, it is cutting edge and stylish. The razor fits easily into the hand and while running the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver is quieter than the unit it replaces. The small collapsible trimmer in the back of the unit works well.<br /><br />The SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver is cordless and comes with a charging stand that can automatically switch to the prevailing voltage, so traveling overseas will not be an issue. It also comes with a carrying case large enough to hold everything that comes with the razor, including the charging base, and a small cleaning brush.<br /><br />I have owned three other Norelco razors, and the only one that shaves as close as the Advantage 7735X was the Advantage 5655. On balance I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver, so much so that I think I'll be going back to the tried and true Advantage 7735X, or perhaps try a new lotion pack model; the lotion packs agree with my skin.<br /><br />And the really good news for my fellow razor bump suffers: I have not had a single bump since I started shaving with the SensoTouch 3D 1250x Electric Shaver that at least is plus for the razor.

  373. Been using for about a month now. I basically bought this to shave my neck 3-4 times a week. I have a thick, coarse beard. I read LOADS AND LOADS of reviews and comparisons all over the internet. I decided on an electric razor instead of a safety blade and eventually came down to this one because it was on sale for about $40 less than the competition.<br /><br />I can say that with my beard, this does NOT shave all of my hairs on my neck. I always have to flip up the small &#34;straight section&#34; on this shaver to pickup where the circular area does not get. It's always in the same place too. That said, it's not a big deal, the fact that it comes with the little flip-up straight section makes it just fine.<br /><br />Cleaning is really easy. You flip open the blades, run under water, and you're done. You don't need solution or the self-cleaning thing, it's pointless. With my thick neck beard - I literally take 1-2 minutes doing circles, 30 seconds pickingup the extras with the straight part, then 15 seconds cleaning in running water.<br /><br />This comes with a charging stand - awesome.<br /><br />I'm very happy with this overall. I may update my review down the line.

AND with this product, I have opportunity for a dry shave or I can use water, or I can use lather or I can use lotion.<br />For anyone who likes an electric shave this is the best product I've ever had.

  429. So far this has been the best electric razor I have ever had. I bought it almost 2 years and it still works flawlessly. I'm in the Navy... so took it on a 10 month deployment using it every day... never failed. It always giving me a close perfect shave every time requireing a charge every 2 to 3 weeks. I replaced the RQ12 head once and clean it with water every time I use it and that's it. Highly recommended.

  436. This razor works great!
  437. This is my first electric shaver. After using razor blades for decades, I switched to the Norelco 1250 Sensotouch.<br /><br />Yes, it did take me time to adjust. My neck broke out at first. And the razor pulled hairs occasionally. But no longer. Here's why: The beard and skin did take some time to adjust from manual to electric, just like 'they' say. And I had to figure out 1) which pre-shave to use and 2) which aftershave lotion worked best, and 3) how to use an electric shaver, especially which directions to shave and which part of the face to shave first. (See tips below that helped me.)<br /><br />I chose between this Norelco rotary and the Braun 7 foil. Deciding factors: the Norelco is comparatively quieter; it's easier to clean (which becomes even more important when traveling); and it's smaller than the Braun. FOR ME, I feel like I made the best choice. BTW, I have a medium (not too heavy) beard and don't have too many problems with ingrown hairs or serious breakouts.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-- Battery is great. You can charge as often or a little as you wish (lasts about two weeks between charges); charging frequency doesn't affect a lithium battery.<br />-- Shaver washes easily and quickly (about 15 seconds); no need for the jet clean system, but it might be a nice luxury.<br />-- Fast, easy, and often... After getting the hang of it, I can now shave in a couple of minutes. And even after shaving in the morning, I can shave early evening for very special occasions, then shave again the next morning. Shaving often is not only ok, but is even better with an electric. With a manual razor, I couldn't shave more than once in 24 hours, and I always skipped a day whenever I could. Now I can shave with a shirt on and with no mess!<br />-- Quality...Shaver seems well made and sturdy/solid. Fits very comfortable in the hand.<br />-- Portability... Fine and sturdy for travel. No charging stand or cord is needed unless gone for more than about two weeks.<br />-- Lownoise level - when compared to all foil shavers.<br /><br />CONS:<br />Hmmm...Hard to say. The replacement head will cost about $52 (Amazon), but that's only once a year. Maybe I'll wish I could plug the cord directly into it, so I wouldn't need the charging stand when traveling. But their latest stand folds more flatly than their previous stand, so if that's an issue, be sure to get the latest version. (Other than the folding stand, the current 1250 is the same as before.)<br /><br />TIPS that worked for me:<br /><br />Shave with your skin as dry as possible. With my schedule, when I shave in the morning, I need to shave within 15 minutes after showering. To speed the drying of the skin and beard, many men use an alcohol-based pre-shave lotion. The alcohol dries the skin and makes the hair stand up and, therefore, helps the shave glide across the skin without dragging. Alcohol works for most guys, but my face didn't like it. So if your face hates alcohol, try powder. Remington makes a wonderful, inexpensive powder stick, FACE SAVER, that is quick and easy to use. Sounds weird and messy, but it works fine. It's talc based, which is fine for me. It's always not easy to find, but some stores carry it and it is easily available online, including Amazon. Some people use a cornstarch-based baby powder. But for me, the Face Saver is a perfect way to get a quicker, slicker shave, even after showering.<br /><br />Shave the neck and sensitive areas first, while the shaver isn't too warm. Shave with the grain at first. Don't press too hard. After shaving, apply face or even body lotion. Use a fragrant-free lotion, if your skin is sensitive. For me, CeraVe and Lubriderm work fine. Lab Series Ultra Razor Burn Lotion also works great. It's expensive per bottle, but a bottle lasts a long time. And -- this is probably optional -- I use a simple exfoliating face wash in the shower 2 or 3 times a week. Sounds like a lot of fussy trouble (NEVER thought I'd do anything like this), but it's really not a big deal. Doesn't take any longer, just keep the tube in the shower.<br /><br />Last tip: Have patience. It's true what they say - it may take a couple of weeks for your face to adjust and for you to figure out what you're doing. Hope this helps.
  438. The shave is as good as any Norelco shaver, but it is much easier to clean and maintain! It holds it's charge sufficiently so you don't have to keep returning it to it's stand.
  439. This Norelco replaces my old Braun 8585. I couldn't be more pleased with the Norelco, it shaves very close, and very quickly. It's pivoting head is amazingly comfortable, and it's easy to clean...it even tells you when. Quick charging, efficient. Highly recommend!

The CHEAPEST one available is $106 with shipping. To pay $106 for a replacement head when a new unit costs $179 is just plain nuts. I bought a Chinese knockoff replacement on ebay for $30 which fell to pieces when I tried to replace the head. Don't waste your money on this one.

  450. I'm not a big fan of electric shavers, I find them to provide a less than perfect shave - leaving blotches of hair and not being close enough, this electric shaver, however, is in my opinion the closest you can get to a razor shave. I have been using it for the last month and I think that I'm now ready to provide an accurate and detailed review. I have used these criteria to review this product: Quality of shave, Ease of cleaning, Comfort level, Battery usage and Overall value for money. The electric shaver in question excels in most of these areas: Quality of shave The new \\"3d\\" head, although gimmicky in title, is very percise and does not leave any area untreated, however, just like any other electric shaver, this too doesn't provide the close shave that can be attained by an actual razor shave. 4 Out of 5 Ease of cleaning The detachable head is extremely easy to clean and really does come out clean when you are done, no place for the hairs to hide so to speak 5 Out of 5 Comfort level The shaver fits perfectly in the hand and has a good feel to it, it feels like some thought was put into it's design and top quality materials were used in the manufacturing process. This can also be observed by the incredibly silent operation, even after a month. 4 Out of 5 Battery The battery lasts enough for a several shaves, and charging an empty battery is incredibly fast, can't ask for more in this department. 5 Out of 5 Value for money Here's where it falls short - the price is high, and if you can afford it you get an high quality electric shaver at a premium, but for most of us, this is just not worth the money. 3 Out of 5 Conclusion As a whole, this is a very good electric shaver and if the price were to go down slightly, it's star rating would improve, but for now it gets a 4 Out of 5 If you liked this review, please mark it as helpful!

  461. Over the last 3 months I've used the Panasonic LA-93K, Braun 760cc and the Noreclco 1250x/40. I'm 33 years old and I've been usuing an electric razor almost for as long as I've had to shave. For the last 6 -7 years I've used top of the line Braun razors and prior had tried a Norelco, the wet / dry version that dispensed shaving lotion. I started my search for a new razor when my old Braun, top of the line at the time, Model # 8589 started to faulter. I'm a very tough customer as I've got extremely sensitive skin in my neck area. The whiskers also grow in all different directions which causes ingrown hairs. My neck area requires multiple passes which adds to the irritation. I've never had a razor that didn't irritate my neck and leave some stray whiskers behind. The problem has only gotten worse with age. I've tried shaving with a Gillet Fusion straigh razor, it irritated my neck area more than any of the electric razors. I started my journey witht the LA-93K - I read the reviews on Amazon as was extremely excited to give the razor a shot. I shaved with it dry, wet and with shaving cream. I had to make a lot of passes with the razor in the neck area and it still left hair behind. My neck area became very irriated after shaving due to the multiple passes. I had to pull out my old Braun to clean up after shaving with the LA-93K. The razor was very loud and the shave head was bulky. It did however seem to cut closer than the Braun or Noreclo, five O'Clock shadow stayed away longer. I returned the Razor to Amazon after 3 weeks of use, the return was very easy, was very pleased with Amazon's customer service. I then gave the Braun 760cc a shot. The head seems to countor to my face better than the LA-93K but from a performance stand point I didn't see an improvement over my old Braun or the Panasonic. It actually seemed to irritate my kneck more than my old Braun. I tried all 3 shaving settings. The shave was more comfortable for me than the LA-93K but not drastically differet. My last stop was the Norelco 1250X/40 - I was desperate at this point. I had shyed away from Norelco in the past due to the circular motion needed to shave with the rotary heads, in the past this had cuased more irritaiton than the foil shavers. I was surprised by how well the shaving heads countored to my face. I tried the shaver with shaving lotion, worked great, glided and really seemed to limit the irriation. Using the Panasonic with shaving cream seemed to actually add to the irritation. The razor is very quite compared to the Panasonic and Braun. For me it does a better job if gettin the pesky whiskers and irritates my skin less. It is extremely easy to clean, I wouldn't spend money on the more expensive models, they all have the same shaving head and performance, the add ons are the cleaning station and more advanced display screens. It doesn't give me a perfect shave but closer to perfection than the others with less irritation. Each shave has gotten better, I've used the razor around 10 times so far. I've read a lot of reviews and researched a lot of razors over the last 3 - 4 months. What I've learned is a razor is a personal preference and everyones skin, hair growth pattern exc... is different. So you've really got to give razors a shot and see which one works best for you. All these models have trial periods and I didn't run into any issues returning the Panasonic or Braun. For me, the Noreclco was the winner of the big 3.
  462. This razor is quieter & more comfortable than my Norelco 7775X. However, it does not shave as close. I find that comfort & closeness are trade-offs to some degree. This razor is not worth the extra money.

  498. After my Braun series 3 decided to wig out, I spent some time on Amazon reading review after review on electric shavers and even digging through Consumer Reports. Having been a Braun fan for most of my life, the last experience just didn't set with me all too well. On the other hand, spending nearly $170 wasn't high on my priority list either. After much anxiety, I bit the bullet and decided to purchase this Norelco shaver. Boy am I glad I did. This product, hands down, is the closest shave I've had from an electric shaver. Another big plus is that it is 1/4 of the noise of my Braun. In fact, I can wake up in the morning, head to the bathroom and feel as though I'm still being quiet while shaving -- a plus with an infant in the house. I was very impressed at how smooth it glides on my skin and how it got to every size of hair. The other thing is that it takes one pass to clear my stubble as compared to my Braun which I felt I had to go over the same area twice. Thus, my shaving time was cut in half. Another benefit is that I don't end up getting the five o'clock shadow as bad as I usually do. My four year old made the comment the other day that he liked that I didn't have a 'sharp beard'. I wouldn't spend the extra money to get the jet wash unit. Frankly, I just run it under some hot water and it does the job just fine. So far the battery life is exemplary. This was a great purchase and the packaging and delivery were right on target.

You also have to clean this shaver after every use because of the very small collection chambers.
