  504. I am a bit of a perfectionist when it comes to electric shaving. For decades, I have used a Norelco (Philips) to rough-in and a Braun to finish up. Braun still gives a slightly closer shave, but they are not ideal as a solo unit if you have a heavy beard. After using a variety of Norelcos since the early 1970's, I can state unequivocally that this is by far the best yet. It is easy to see why; you see those big circumferential slots in the second concentric ring of the heads? Those allow longer hairs to easily gain entrance into the cutting heads and be dealt with. The 3D is the only shaver in the lineup thus far to have them. Combined with the inward-and-outward flexibility of the 3D's heads, this is a major advance. With my previous Norelco's, I would consistently have long hairs under my chin or around the \\"Adam's Apple\\" that would require five or six passes to chop down. Sometimes, I would have to revert to using the sideburn trimmer to get them. After using the 3D for three weeks, I have seen no trace of any hair eluding the wrath of the 3D's cutting blades. Hopefully, the \\"large-slot\\" heads will work their way down the product line; until then it's well worth paying the extra money for the 3D.
  505. The GOOD news: This shaver which looks a bit like a small Martian creature gives me the most rapid and close shaves ever. The BAD news: The shaver comes with a combined holder and charging unit which, when the shaver is docked, is unstable on my bathroom counter. The least jostling causes the unit to fall over and half the time it ends up on the tile floor. The fourth time this happened the plastic shaver head protector shattered with no damage to the shaver itself. The unit comes with excellent instructions that indicate that the shaver should be washed with hot water after each use and that no blotting of the shaver head is allowed for fear of lint getting into the shaver head. They also recommend replacing the shaver heads yearly -at a cost upwards of $50.
  506. Over the years, I've used a lot of different Norelco shavers, in some cases bringing them in to local shops to replace the batteries. My beard, thin but wiry, is too challenging for most other brands. However, I was never completely happy with the previous Norelco that I bought several years ago (an XL model) and I really wanted to try one of the 3D styles. The 1250x/40 was perfect for me because I shave my face dry, so cleaning isn't a big issue. I had no real interest in paying the extra $100 (plus supply costs) for the cleaning unit when just blowing out and rinsing the heads after a shave is about all that I needed. The one benefit of the top model that I do miss is the accurate display of remaining shaves. That would be an issue when I travel a lot (more on that later). I wish Norelco would make that model available without the cleaning unit. Though this really shouldn't matter, this has to be one of the most attractive shavers Norelco has ever designed. With the curvy black body and nicely coordinated charging stand, the 1250x wouldn't look out of place on Darth Vader's bathroom vanity. It's a real beauty. The slip-over cover for the 3D heads was the first I've owned that didn't break after the first few months. This was also the first Norelco shaver that provided good results from day one. Though Norelco says that it takes about 30 days for your face to get used to its shaving heads, I think the reality is that it normally takes that long for the blades to wear to a point where they seat correctly in the shaving head. (You experience the same \\"break-in\\" period when These seemed to be perfect from the first, possibly explained by the fact that the blade replacement cost is roughly double what Norelco charges for non-3D models. The shave is very close, even and comfortable. It isn't necessarily faster than other Norelco models, but the results are notably better. Compared to most of Norelco's other shavers, the 1250 is very light, apparently because it uses a smaller battery. For me, it holds a charge for about 3 weeks of daily shaving. Getting the last green light of the charge indicator means I have 3-6 days left before a recharge--not a particularly accurate indicator. If you're traveling a lot that can be an issue. For user safety reasons, the charger plugs into the shaver stand and not the shaver itself, meaning you have to bring both along when you travel and there's no way to run the shaver directly on AC. There's a nice travel case for the shaver, but nothing for the stand, which takes up nearly as much space and not really meant for a travel bag. There were a couple of minor, but very nice touches that I really liked. The suction cups on the base of the charging stand keeps it solid and secure in spite of the fact that it's very light. The other is the velcro strap to keep the able on the power adapter coiled neatly when it's not in use. Because of the limited charge and need for a charging stand, this might not be the ideal traveling companion for road warriors, but otherwise I would give this shaver my highest recommendation. It's one of the best values in Norelco's product line and I found an excellent deal on this site.
  507. The product is very nice, and the express is so fast. I help my friend to buy it. My friend think that it is worthy to recommend to them.
  508. I received this razor for Christmas and had not shaved in a couple of days. It is exactly as described. It was a very close shave and the best part was there wasn't any tugs or pulls like previous electric razors I have used. Great Job Norelco

It's lightweight, conforms to you face very well, and really does get the longer hairs with ease. With other razors I had to keep going over the same spots but this one does it in only a few swipes. Easy day! I did not get the cleaning station and I have yet to see what happens when I use shaving cream with it... likely it will not go very well, but I'll give it a try.
  510. A year ago my Spectra broke. So, I got a cheaper Norelco ($80.00) and have been unhappy for the last year. You only get what you pay for. I've used a Norelco for over 20 years and the Senso Touch 3D is a great shave. I have a beard which means I shave only my neck, the hardest part of the shave. And this razor does it perfectly. It even shaves cleanly along the beard line without pulling any hairs from the beard. I couldn't be happier. I only have one caution. This is not a good razor for travelling. If you lose the charging stand or break it you forgoe the opportunity to charge the razor until you replae the charging stand. Yes, it looks good. But whoever designed the concept did not take into consideration that things can get broken or lost. There is no more plugging the charger directly into the razor.

  513. I will be brief. While the aesthetics of this 1250x/40 is very pleasant, its day-by-day use is impractical. Not recommended at all to anyone who really needs a shaver! I bought mine three weeks ago, and I am an international buyer. Unfortunately, I tore the packaging away before boarding the plane back to Brazil. Keep the packaging because you will need it to get a refund/return the product! 1. the charging stand is bulky, fragile and does not secure the shaver firmly. To make it even worse, the stand is required to have the shaver charged, since the power cord won't plug directly to the shaver. Thus, if you travel a lot, you will have to carry the shaver, the charging stand and the power cord, but keep in mind that only the shaver fits the carrying pouch! 2. the shaver makes a mess! I will copy Neil E. Lazinsky's post here: \\"the stubble does not stay in the shaver!! It is constantly falling out as you shave, especially if the razor heads are turned downward at all, which happens often, including when you try to use the absurdly positioned trimmer, and it makes a big mess! You also have to clean this shaver after every use because of the very small collection chambers\\". In summary: you will have hair debris spread all over while shaving! 3. the blades won't reach just below the nostrils. Due to a very large plastic border around the cutting heads, I simply can't get the shaver to reach the stubbles by my nostrils. I have to resort to my 12y old philips shaver to get the job done... That's it for now. I will keep this review updated as I keep using the product. I hope my unit won't stop working all of a sudden as many have reported...

So I'm like, the only way to use the razor is to charge it with the charger Panasonic included with the razor, but that's not covered......seems pretty ridiculous. So I've not had a razor now for a week because they mis-typed my address shipping the new handle....and now another 2 weeks for a charger. That's hard on someone that shaves every day.   549. I came from a lower end Philips rotary head shaver and decided I wanted the more flexible head.<br />This shaver was a definite step up, with the Norelco head flexing around the chin and jawline really well.<br />The battery life is good, with one charge giving me two weeks, with one 2-5min shave per day. The charging and cleaning indicators are really useful.<br />Cleaning the device is really easily, involving open the three shaver heads and running it under water.<br />The shaving experience is good, involving minimal pressure, except for the stubborn longer hairs, which can be removed with a little bit more effort.<br />I do most of my shaving dry, as I am to lazy to use foam or gel. This shaver does a great job and hasn't caused me any shaver rash or discomfort.<br />I have used it with foam and it glides really well and maybe does a slightly better job, if not taking a bit longer.<br />The in built beard trimmer is pretty useful and tucks away, so it is almost forgotten.
  550. I have always had a problem with electric razors because my beard is rather light. If I forget to shave the fine hairs were not getting trimmed so I was using two different electric razors. It is quiet, efficient and even the trimmer is interesting because the razor is so quiet you can hear it as it finds and cuts hairs, it makes a little popping like sound.   554. Pro: The only really good thing about the 1255x is the noise: 67 db at 6 inches is about a quarter as loud as the Braun Series 7 (79-80 db); with the Braun Series 5 in the middle. (The decibel scale is logarithmic, not linear.)<br /><br />Con:<br />Abrasion - This was the show stopper. On my third use, I had substantial abrasion under my chin (also some abrasion on earlier use). With an electric shaver, it is important to stretch the skin you are shaving and to shave against the grain, as it were. (Using a Braun, I have cut myself under my mouth, when I failed to stretch, but I have never had significant abrasion. Rotary shaving is multi-directional, while the Brauns make shaving against the grain easier.)<br />Charging - This shaver charges only on its stand, which seems OK when you are at home. When traveling, the stand will be an inconvenience, and it might get broken. The instructions say to unplug the small wall-wart when not charging - do not charge continuously - another liability. (I dump my Braun into the more convenient, connected charger/cleaner whenever I am at home.)<br />Cleaning - Flip open each of the three heads and clean under running water. Then leave the heads open to dry. This means you cannot pack it up for travel, and it is more vulnerable to damage when open. Cleaning in water and air-drying cannot be good for cutting edges.<br />Trimmer - the only trimmer I have tried that is unacceptable for getting those hairs that sneak out my ears.<br /><br />Other: Fully charged in 1 hour. Put finger behind a rotor to improve shaving of upper lip. Can shave wet (not tested); this might be the forte of the shaver, but I want to shave dry. The 1255x appears to be the same as the 1250x, but with an extra head included. Philips/Norelco recommends using for three weeks - without using another shaver - as a fair test. I judged the 1255x could not get as good as the Braun Series 5 with such a test, so I quit. I was relieved to get back to theBraun. YMMV.<br /><br />Related products I have reviewed:<br />[[ASIN:B0020MMCB6 Braun Series 3 370 Men's Shaver]] (Pete: 2-stars)<br />[[ASIN:B003YJAZZ4 Braun Series 7- 790cc Pulsonic Shaver System, Silver]] (Pete: 4-stars)<br />[[ASIN:B003YJB026 Braun Series 5-550cc Shaver System, Black and Silver]] (Pete: 4-stars)
  555. This is the best shaver ever created by mankind. I have VERY sensitive skin. Shaving has always hurt even shaving with the grain. This one makes it easier and doesn't hurt as much. The only thing is around the adam's apple and near my ears but that's impossible with me. I have trouble with a straight razor. So, I can't really hold that against it. Anyway, well worth the purchase. I love how I can wet shave with it. It's easy to clean without the station. I didn't get the station. You use hot water when the three circular blade compartments are closed (like it is when you shave) and then cold water when you open the three blade compartments. That's it. I wish I would have found this sooner.
  556. Bought this back in March. Worked great out of the box. 4 months later - here's what I think. Pros - still sleek and quiet, does a good job on cheeks. Cons - Don't like popping the heads open individually to clean - can't seem to get them or keep them clean, leaves long hairs on side burns and under nose, hate the fact that I can't plug directly into shaver - need to take stand on trips to recharge.   557. First the good:<br />- The quality of the shave is excellent (I shave in the shower with the water running)<br />- The length of the battery life is also very impressive. (I'm frequently away for 2-3 weeks, and I do not need to bring a charger with me).<br />- The ease of cleaning is also excellent; I simply open the heads and run the shower on them for a few seconds, cleaning everything, after I'm finished shaving.<br /><br />Now the bad.<br />- After about 10 months, the on/off button began to stick for me. Finally it got to the point where I was not able to turn the shaver on or off at all. Philips quickly sent me out a new shaver as it was under warranty, so good service. However, now about 11 months later, the exact same problem is occurring with the replacement I was sent. The on/off button is starting to stick/fail to function. For the exact same problem to happen twice with different models tells me there has got to be some kind of manufacturing problem with the device. I don't see too many other reviewers complaining about this problem (which surprises me), so perhaps it has something to do with the water where I am (slightly high in calcium), or the fact I shave in the shower. (Note the instructions clearly do say you can use it in the shower and the shaver is supposed to be waterproof).<br /><br />Despite the high quality shave, and the good service, manufacturing defects mean I cannot recommend this product and I would not buy it again.
  558. I've had a Braun shaver for a long time - but the shaving head became faulty - so I have tried the Philips SensoTouch 3D.<br />The Philips is much much quieter than the Braun, with much less vibration too.<br />I also found the shave to be much closer than my Braun.<br />However, the Philips is noticeably larger.<br />Especially the shaving head - it is much larger.<br />And you have to shave using an unconventional \\"circular\\" motion.<br />However, I cannot complain - as it is superior to the Braun - without a doubt.
  559. Short hairs were easy to cut, and this razor provided a comfortable and close shave. Shaving without water was actually really convenient and helped me get ready faster in the morning.<br /><br />The extendable hair trimmer is a convenient and not very powerful, but it works alright for cleaning up side burns with a few presses on the same spot. Also, if one has a longer stubble, one might use the extendable trimmer to do a first pass or to get a pesky long hair or two.<br /><br />Long hairs on my neck were not cut well by the rotary blades. I tried pulling my skin tight, different patterns, and even flipping the razor upside down to use different blades. I would have to press considerably hard with the head on the skin, pluck those hairs, or use the extendable trimmer in these situations (many times it was a combination).<br /><br />The body of my razor got a white tinge that wasn't cleanable after two months.<br /><br />The razor battery is very good. It lasted me over three weeks from shaving every three days or so. I think it would have lasted longer. When charging the product, my razor emitted a high frequency ringing sound. Pulling the razor off the dock and putting it back on a few times caused the ringing to stop, but that noise did annoy me.
  560. If you like the stubble look this is for you,or if your a female perfect for your legs. Men need not apply! Nowhere near a blade!
  561. it was very good quality and packaged well, it was a present and it arrived right on time and I got it for a great price
  562. I've been a long time electric shaver user--and always Norelco. This is by far the best shave I've ever gotten. The heads follow the contours of my face better than any conventional three head shaver could. As others have mentioned, clean-up is always very easy. Haven't tried wet shaving with cream yet, but I'm getting such a nice shave without that I probably won't bother. My only observation is that the sideburn trimmer is not quite as usable as the one on my other razors. It's a little harder to use it to trim back the bulk of my sideburns, but that's a minor complaint.<br /><br />There are a bunch of different 3D models but they primarily differ in the features that don't directly relate to the shave, such as the battery life indicator.<br /><br />If you've never tried an electric, this would be a good choice. Don't go cheap. There are $50 coupons floating around for the 3D models.
  563. It just does not shave well. Perhaps it was made on a Monday or Friday as the old saying goes but I have bought many products from Amazon and this is the first negative I have ever responded with.<br /><br />Rev. V.Neil Wyrick
  564. Fantastic product! Very quiet, great shave. I love this. Retains charge for long periods of time.
  565. Excellent shaver, better than the other 7000 or 8000 philips series shavers I had. Worth the money, and excellent service from Amazon as always even delivering to Australia. The same model shaver sell for over AUD400 in the local dept stores here in Sydney, Amazon is the way to go
  566. I found the three top of the line electric shavers - Braun Series 7, Panasonic es-la63, and Phillips Norelco 3D - to be so similar as to recommend any of them as excellent shavers, but each has its strengths and weaknesses. Too many reviewers are only comparing the closeness of the shave, but that's only one factor of several that may be most important. Here's my breakdown: Closeness - Let's start with the most popular category. If all you care about is how close you can shave, then I rate the wet-shaved Panasonic and Norelco even, BUT ONLY when coupled with a shaving oil/gel combo such as [[ASIN:B005ACNPLO Remington Alphagel Sensitive Shave Gel 5 oz. (Pack of 2)]] (there's a cooling menthol version as well). Another way to accomplish the same thing is by using [[ASIN:B0023XF60Q SHAVE SECRET SHAVING OIL- THE BEST SHAVE EVER! 18.75ML]] topped with [[ASIN:B0032ANCUU Edge Shave Gel, Senstive Skin, 7-Ounces Cans (Pack of 6)]]. These provide the closest shave possible, but, of course, it's messy, takes a lot of extra time, and can be a general pain. There's no advantage in closeness to using non-oil shaving cream by itself. Going dry-shave, I may give the tiniest of edges to Panasonic over Braun and Norelco, but all three are awfully close - to each other and in quality of shave. Speed - If you're in a hurry and want to get in and get out with a dry-shave as quickly as possible, the Norelco wins. The Panasonic is next followed by the Braun. Comfort - I don't have sensitive skin, but the Braun wins out (unless going wet-shave with the oil/gel as described above). The Braun has three speeds so you can go slower for sensitive areas and intensive on less-sensitive places. I just leave it set on intensive all the time and have no problem. The Panasonic is next followed by the Norelco third. The wet-shaving Panasonic and Norelco are the most comfortable of all if you want to put up with the oil/gel prep and clean-up time. Cleaning - Any auto cleaning system is easier than manual cleaning. Just pop in the shaver and press a button. That said, the Braun is the only system with alcohol in its cleaner to sanitize as well as a detergent to clean and oil to lubricate. Norelco's apparently has detergent and lubrication. From what I've been able to tell, the Panasonic solution is only a detergent. Manually, the Norelco is easiest to clean and you can duplicate the auto clean by pouring some of its [[ASIN:B002DHVAZW Philips Norelco HQ200 Jet Clean Solution]] in a dish or mug and whirring the shaver in it for 30 seconds after shaving. The Panasonic and Braun can be rinsed off under a faucet. The Panasonic's special cleaning speed makes it slightly easier to manually clean than the Braun. Maneuverability - If you have a moustache, goatee, beard, long sideburns, or whatever this is a very important category. The Braun is king here with the Norelco second and the larger-head Panasonic last. Noise - You can hardly hear the Norelco at all. The Braun is a little buzzy and the Panasonic loudest although not irritatingly so. Still, a sleeping spouse nearby will appreciate you using the Norelco most. Travel - The Norelco is last in this category because you'll need to bring the charging stand with you. The Norelco soft case does not hold the stand so that's a bit of a drawback. The Braun's harder case gives it top honors over the Panasonic's soft one, but the Panasonic has an on-off lock that the Braun lacks. Perhaps the Braun doesn't need it because the case is harder, and also because the Braun is the only shaver that can run while plugged in with a depleted battery. The other two require a 5-minute charge to give you a few minutes shave. A fully-charged shaver gives you about 50 minutes in each.
  567. I no longer use my straight razor with shaving brush/shave soap. This shaver shaves very close and even gets the long hairs on my neck that my Braun electric shaver could not get. I highly recomend this shaver, you will be happy with it.

He says it delivers the fastest cutting speed he has ever experienced, and he is careful to always buy the shavers highest recommended on Consumer Reports. He likes the added perk of the stand having tiny suction cups on the bottom so that it doesn't slide around on the counter. He claims of all the shavers he's bought, this one is his favorite.
  569. I bought this shaver with a lot of excitement and after reading scores of reviews. But, after trying it out for a few days, I have decided that this will be my first Amazon Return. The shave quality is ridiculously bad in the neck area, even on plain non-groovy areas of the chest (yes, I had to try it). I had to move the shaver in many different angles and it still decided to leave behind a lot of isolated hair! It just seems like it is lacking the power to do the job right. That being said, I think that most $50 electric shavers will provide a better shave than this fancy GyroFlex gimmick. And my experience supports that argument. Do not waste your time and money if you have fairly thick hair.

It does not matter if you have an extented warranty or not.<br /><br />Basically I was told that if you expect Philips to support one of their products that you bought from them you might have to hold your breath a long time.<br /><br />I now have a policy to not buy any product with a Philips name on it.<br /><br />Good luck if your product never fails.
  571. When my Braun 5000 series shaver died I wanted to get back to the rotary shavers by Norelco. I had never liked the shave I got from my Braun. Since getting the shaver 3 weeks ago my shave times have been cut down by two-thirds. Rarely do I have to go over an area twice and it picks up the hair on my neck as if it were my cheek. It is super quiet and easy to clean. I shave 3 times a week and I am still working on my initial charge from when I received it 3is weeks ago. The shaver is not perfect: the trimmer is a little lacking, the power button is right where my thumb usually rests when shaving, and you can not shave and have it charge at the same time since the only way to charge it is through the charging base. There is no charging plug on the razor itself. I have already recommended this to a friend. I just hope this has the same durability as previous Norelco products I have used in the past.
  572. I tried the Panasonic which cut the beard but took multiple passes for a close shave and it was extremely noisy! So I ordered a new 1250-40 model norelco and now I get the quiet shave and efficiency in beard handling. Yes you do have to go over some area a few times but that's only for the first 10 shaves than your beard adjusts to the rotary shaving and its just a couple of passes to catch everything. Cleaning the unit is a bit awkward in that you lift each individual head to clean out the hairs (but at least it collects the cuttings unlike the Panasonic which just let them fall in the sink as you shaved). I like this razor - its my third norelco in 30 years. Guess I am hooked! One other noted feature is the SensoTouch 3d heads which move around all the curves of you face and jaw to get to the finny growths on the neck line and around the jawline. Recommend this over the Panasonic hands down.

The shipping was free because I am an Amazon Prime customer. After charging I was surprised to find it shaved under my chin, something no other electric could ever do. The mustache and chin were well shaved with this razor. Had a problem with the sides of my face due to, well, having a somewhat flabby face. This model was made in 2010 making it about two years old. This ain't new but it the latest thing Norelco has to offer. The $30.oo rebate means that there are new models on the event horizon after Xmas I assume. There are no free lunches and no real bargains out there. Razor technology has reached its highest level. Don't see a new and improved mousetrap/razor. The only foible I found with this razor after a few spins around the block (my face) is with the clipping device. It is poor. My cheap Norelco razor for $39.95 has a much better clipping device than this pricy 1250x/40. All in all I got a pretty good deal with my Amazon Rewards cash. Free shipping. Less tax to pay too.   578. Purchased the 1250x as an upgrade to my 2 year old philips norelco that looks similar in form. The heads on the old one were getting gross and instead of paying for new heads (which can cost as much as upgrading) got this 1250x instead. PROS: *Sleek design *longer battery life than previous generations, good for travel *can be used wet or dry *easy to clean flip out heads *shaves very close without any \\"tugging\\" of the hairs or skin! CONS *the pop-out trimmer is actually less useful than the previous gens for me, it is also a bit smaller in size which I see as a disadvantage. The previous models pop-out trimmer actually flipped out and was a decent size. The 1250x trimmer slides out and seems smaller in width which makes trimming sideburns etc actually take longer. As a precision trimmer it works OK, but I much prefer the old trimmer size and pop-out method.
  579. Smooth, fast, no neck burn, quiet, close shave. Easy to clean. Trimmer is only mediocre; both lack of reach and cutting action (less effective than my 10 yr. old Norelco trimmer). Pleasure to use.

  581. I replaced my old Panasonic 2 blades shaver with this 1250X. It is a lot more quiet. I shaved for 4 days and the battery indicator drops by 1 bar out of 3, I think it is reasonable, although my Panasonic usually could last for 2-3 weeks per charge. It provides a quick and clean shave. In order to have a clean shave, the Panasonic design needs to you pay attention to where and the movement to shave. Rather this Philips 1250X, I could just randomly move it in circular motion, and it does the job, i.e. I pay less attention and have the same result. Grab design is good, and easy to hold. It gives me face burn especially at the neck area a lot for the first few shaves, but it is going away. Overall, it is an excellent shaver.<br /><br />Only catch is the replacement shaver head is very expensive, $60-70!! Beware. Hopefully I don't have to replace it every year as recommended!
  582. I've been shaving for about 30 years, about 25 with various electric razors (usually Norelco). I upgraded this time from the standard Norelco, and couldn't be happier.   585. I've been trying to break away from using a standard razor blade and went with the electric razor when it was on sale. The shave is inadequate in many ways. The razor head is huge and covers a broad area of the face which makes it difficult to see what you are doing causing you to stop and remove the electric razor to see your progress. Because of the plastic around the rotary blades it is difficult to get to the edges of your shave which they tried to solve with a secondary straight razor for the sideburns but still is not good for upper lip area and anything beyond the sideburns. The problem is the shave is not going to be even. I have relatively \\"tight\\" skin and somewhat thicker facial hair and shaving both dry and wet not only took longer than a normal non electric razor but I had to use a normal non electric razor to take care of all the areas missed. Between the bulky head and the uneven shave it is just not a good buy.

  587. My past shaver was a cheap Panasonic wet/dry dual blade (ES4026NC). It was a bit noisy and vibrated a lot. Shave wise it didn't catch strays that well unless I pre-trimmed with the pop-up trimmer. My once a week or month shave would take up to 30 minutes, at the end of which I would have a cramped neck and sore face.<br />So I decided to splurge this xmas and get myself the 1250x (1255x was the specific box item) from the large bulk membership-required store. It included an extra replacement shaving head so it was a better deal than elsewhere. First thing I noticed about the shaver was the cool battery meter. Instead of the individual LED bars this shaver has a black-out panel that only lights up when charging or when turning on/off. Very stealth! Speaking of stealth, this thing is super quiet. After charging the unit fully I powered it up and proceeded to shave my slobbish face with 1/3\\" hairs. Pressed the power button... \\"Is this thing on? Why's it so quiet?\\" Indeed it was on. Using the recommended circular pattern I watched my face transform from ruffian to gentleman. Wow, no pre-trim necessary!<br />Some areas did require more than one pass but I was able to finish shaving in personal record time. And no neck cramp to boot! With the impressive results and ease of use I could see shaving being a daily or weekly routine. More importantly the gf approves of the clean shave instead of prickly stubble or ruffian appearance.   599. Great shaver. This is done to prevent you from shaving while plugging in the shaver, that is, if for some reason the shaver batteries die and cannot be recharged, you MUST throw away the shaver...and thus buy another one. But it will not be a Phillips, this does it for me.<br /><br />However the shaver shaves very, very well. So far, the batteries are behaving fine. Fingers crossed.

  625. The last time I used an electric razor was on a US Navy Destroyer back in the 50's & 60's, a necessary, unpleasant task, with the only alternative a messy razor and shaving cream. I couldn't believe the difference in the comfort--not to mention convenience--in the 2 experiences: It's like comparing a VW to a Royles Royce. The shaving head conforms perfectly to the contours of your face, takes about half the time of an regular razor, and requires only seconds to clean--just flip up the shaving heads and brush/wash out the residue. I have experienced no skin irritation at any time using this product, and gone are the painful nicks of a razor blade and the drying effects of shaving lotions. I do recommend the 3D model due to its movement in 3 planes, which results in excellent conformation to the contours of your face.

  648. I was literally losing my hearing from my old Panasonic foil shaver, so sound was my primary concern. I was skeptical of getting a rotary, but the marketing was so convincing, and the reputation for being quieter, I couldn't resist. I'm happy with it. It's stylish (so what), easy to clean, shaves like a charm, and is SO QUIET!!! I can actually carry on a conversation or listen to the news while I'm shaving now! I keep mine in a cabinet, delicately balanced on its fragile little charging stand, so I have no concern over the travel ability or not plugging directly into the shaver. If I travel it will be less than two weeks, and since this thing will hold a charge for a long time, I shouldn't have to worry about the charge. I have only used it dry, and the shave is not as close as a blade - thankfully! Blades give me ingrown hairs if I use them regularly, so one reason I use an electric is to NOT shave so close to get ingrowns. I could use this wet, and I may eventually, and I suspect it would shave very close to blade closeness then - but I use a real blade anyway for &#34;date night&#34; with my wife, when I really need to be smooooooth! Update after several months... The pop-up trimmer is pretty pathetic, very narrow, and difficult to get to grab the hair you're cutting - it takes as long to trim my sideburns as it does to shave! Also, I am feeling skin irritation a little more than I did with my old, loud, foil shaver. But I still love how quiet it is, and it still does the job. Update after two years... Well, I can no longer recommend this product. I went shopping for a replacement head, and the price was astronomical for the original equipment kind - almost as much as the shaver cost! The new variety of replacement head is widely reviewed as inferior, but more modestly priced. I said forget it and bought a new Braun, after checking on the availability of replacement parts! So I just reduced the start from 5 to 2. I've never done that before, but you need to know.

Within 5 months the smooth shave was gone completely, replaced by a head that was biting and tearing my skin. It needed to be replaced a full 7 months before the supposed life of the head! New head = brand new shave again - for 5 months. This razor has driven me back to shaving with a blade. My ratings reflect the fact that when everything is fresh and new, the razor works extremely well and is easy to use. But the head wears out too quickly and despite the elegant aesthetic design requiring the entire very expensive head to be replaced two to three times a year (instead of just the blades) is a major industrial design flaw.

  667. What you have to ask yourself is: will this Norelco shave better than the one I already own? And maybe a related question: do I want a better shave, or just a new novelty?<br /><br />Gents, I have to say that I don't find any real difference between how the model 1250X/40 shaves as compared to my six year old 9195XL. So I am returning the new shaver.<br /><br />Very important - get the most out of your Norelco:<br />1. Shaving technique is paramount. Using circular motion is the only way to get the closest shave from a Norelco.<br />2. Change those heads every year - you will feel like you just bought a brand new shaver.<br /><br />And to make your Norelco battery last longer, every six months or so make sure you let the battery run down to below \\"0\\" on the charge indicator - until it stops. (This also applies to cell phones or any other rechargeable battery device.)
  668. I admit that while the design of these shaver had caught my postive attention at first, the purchase price dissuaded me from making the purchase. Recently, after consistently bad shaves with my current shaver, I decided to \\"bite the bullet.\\" Wow, am I impressed! I regret now ever having waited. The manual says it can take up to 21 days for your beard and skin to become used to this shaver, so one should be patient about being satisfied with the initial shaves. My first shave had my face feeling like a babies bottom. It probably took me about a minute to complete the shave. The clean up of the shaver was easy as could be. You simply pop the shaver heads up on their hinge and run warm water through the heads and the well which collects the whiskers. Other positives is that the shaver is very easy to hold with a very light weight. A full charge does take just about an hour as described in the manual. There are several indicator lights on the shaver guiding you when to replace the shaver heads, when to recharge the shave, and when the shaver needs to be cleaned. I would do a TV commercial for this shaver.

  672. I have used a lot of different electric razors over the years and have tried most all brands including different versions of wet/dry but none have given me the close comfortable shave that this one has. Still it is about twice the price of other razors so I was concerned when I bought it about how long it would last. Last week, for no reason I could discern, it stopped charging. To say I was unhappy is an undertatement. I had owned it about a year and decided to try contacting Phillips customer service. The most I hoped for was perhaps a suggestion of things I could try that would fix the problem. It was easy to find the website and very quickly I had selected the live chat option and was explaining my issue with a customer service rep. After some question and answer I was pleased (and a bit surprised) when I was asked for my mailing address and told a new handle would be sent to me. It arrived by Fed Ex in just a few days and it works perfectly. They clearly stand behind their product and that kind of support and the overall quality of the device confirms that it was a good decision to buy this razor.

  684. Been using this piece for about 8 months now and earlier versions of philishave models for more than 10 years. This is truly the best of the lot I have experienced to date. Does it shave better/ closer than the previous ones? Not significantly :) yep that is a fact. At least not when shaving dry. So why is it better? Several reasons, but the most imp is - comfort. It glides much better over my face than any earlier model I've used for dry shaving. None of the earlier models had a wet shaving option so I wondered why would anybody want to shave wet when shaving dry is so convenient and quick. But now dry shaving is the weekday routine when I'm rushing to get ready for office and don't have much time. But on weekends I prefer a wet shave with Gilette series shaving foam. Aah! Now that is where the difference is really tangible. The comfort is like 3 times more with some warm water and foam. It's actually a joy to shave like this as opposed to the daily burden of a dry shave. The finish is twice as better/ closer and the post shave irritation is so much lesser. Other conveniences of this model include the various glowing indicators telling me when the razor needs to be cleaned, charged, etc. The battery life is great! I get about 15+ shaves per full charge. So, if I'm headed out on a week to 10 day trip no need to carry the charger. It is super easy to clean after a wet or dry shave. I use an old tooth brush to clean it after every wet shave. I don't bother cleaning it between 5 to 6 dry shaves, because I don't have the time and I don't think it is needed else it would indicate that, which it does once in a while. The noise and vibration of the motor is also extremely low, in fact if I have the exhaust on in the bathroom I can't even tell that the razor is on or maybe I have a really noisy exhaust :)<br /><br />So all in all, while it's an older model of the new 3D series it is well worth the price.

  693. My old electric razor gave me razor burns on my neck. As the blades got older it got worse. My neck looked like it was scratched by a cat. With the 3D razor I have NO razor burn! I like how the heads contour to the face and I think the the 3D swivel action along with the blade configuration is what makes it all happen. It takes an hour to charge and lasts me over a month so no need to bring a charger with you. Extended trips...the charger takes up about as much room as a phone charger. The three light indicator degreases as the battery life drops and then changes from white to amber red as it gets really low - another nice feature. The unit is light, fits the hand very well, has a convenient pop up trimmer, and can be used, wet, dry, and in the shower. Shaving is a pleasure with my new 3D. It's worth every penny.
  694. I have been using this product for almost a month and have been left with nothing but disappointment. Why?<br />The 1250X SensoTouch 3D began by giving me rashes but I thought that was to be expected trying to get used to a new electric razor, but the rashes, pain and burning continued. The rotary heads are not smooth but pull against my whiskers,especially my upper lip. The rotary heads are not close enough to the edge to do a good job of shaving the upper lip next to the nose, and the heads scrape against the upper lip hair (hurting) and I have to keep going over the same area over and over to get a close shave but it causes a rash and hurts in the process. Because I have to keep going over and over my beard to get a close shave, I find that all that metal on my face heats up and causes a rash and hurts my face, especially my upper lip. For the price, all I can say is this product is ornamental, charges well and is quiet...but I am left to go back to my $30 Panasonic that shaves better, even though it is loud, but my little Panasonic does a better job.   695. My old Norelco 7810XL needed replacment.I purchased the 1150/40 Senso Touch[[ASIN:B003V360NY Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch 2d Electric Shaver, Metallic Blue]] and tried it for a few days (not the 30 recommended) and decided that it was OK but not a great leap forward from the 7810XL.So I decided to take the plunge and spend well over $100 for an electric shaver and got this 1250/40,3D. Only used it for a week but am very glad I spent the extra dollars for it. The third dimension of movement for the shaving heads really does make a difference , particularly on the neck area. My shaves are averaging about two minutes and when done I am very satisfied.<br />Here is what takes some getting used to though.This model(and the 1150/40 for that matter) are not your old fashioned lawn mower type of electric shaver. You know ,turn it on,run it around your face a few times ,turn it of,clean it once a week or so ,and move on. These shavers are much more of a precision instrument,which rewards you with a wonderful shave,if properly maintained. You need to be a little more careful handling it,pay attention to cleaning regularly,like daily,and it will provide a much superior shave as a reward. Cleaning the 1250 ,I would add ,is a snap. Open the three heads brush the interior base ,run the heads under water ,and leave the shaver in the stand with the heads open until dry. Whole process takes less than a minute. One other thing,you really do not need to use any pressure with this shaver while in use. That is what the 3D is all about.Just hold lightly to your face and let the shaver do its thing.<br />I highly recommend this Norelco.
  696. Picked this up @ Wally World on 9/21 for 149.97! Shaved with it 3 days in a row, no irritation! That is not something I could have done with a blade.... and considering how easy it is to clean after use, by simply running it under hot water? Done and done.<br /><br />I never thought I would (or could) say this about any razor, but I truly love this Norelco 1250x. I could not be happier with my purchase.<br /><br />Save your money, avoid the \\"cleaning system\\", and get this razor. It's all you need, less money, and easier to use.
  697. I did a lot of research on Electric Razors before buying this.<br /><br />This unit is the best value in the Phillips Norelco line.   700. I have had it for 3 years now, it is still working.
  701. My problem is not with the shaver. The unit is excellent in almost every way. My problem is with Phillips. The little plastic protection cover for the blades is very weak and flimsy, and breaks easily. The airlines and I have broken two and they are $15 each. They are worth maybe $0.50. The replacement blades can be anywhere from $60 to $150 depending on where you buy them and they last about a year if you don't take them on planes often. The airlines dropped my suitcase breaking the blades. At the time it was cheaper to replace the shaver than the blades. Now it seems the blades have come down to a little more reasonable price, but the fact remains that this is a shaver that works well but must be kept in a very safe place and handled carefully or you'll start spending a lot of money.
  702. Great smooth shave. Much better than the ArciTec model i had.Philips is an outstanding company having pioneered lot of new products over several decades.
  703. I've been on a noble quest for the perfect electric razor after finally giving in and shaving my beard of forty years. Needless to say, when you've spent your whole life NOT shaving, grinding away at your tender face with a blade does not produce agreeable results.So I decided to try this Norelco SensoTouch 3D razor based upon the postitive reviews of you fellow-Amazonites. I have learned a very important lesson...some faces are just not meant to be shaved with a rotary razor. I used this with shaving gel and dry, but never got very good results, and it even began cutting my face in certain sensitive areas, namely above the lip. I gave it the ol' college try for two weeks, trying to get to the magic 45-day trial period nirvana, but I'm a big baby and couldn't stand the constant assault on my mug. I contacted the folks at Norelco, who blew an incredible amount of smoke up my kiester, telling me that this SensoTouch 3D was their finest razor ever, and I should be delirious with satisfaction. I insisted that I wasn't, and no longer wanted to apply tissue to stop the bleeding every morning. They insisted I wage war on my face for the full 45 days before I could send it back. Then, Amazon came riding up on the white steed and told me that if I was not satisfied, then send it back for a full refund. Thanks Amazon! I have since purchased the Braun Series 3 Wet-Dry foil razor (from Amazon) and it has changed my life. I can hardly get a full night's sleep because I can't wait to leap out of bed and stampede to the bathroom to shave. Close, comfortable shave with gel. To conclude, I'm not saying this is a bad product, but it just wasn't a winner for me. If you buy it and can't make it to the 45-day trial period, return it to Amazon within 30 days and try something else. Best of luck to you all.
  704. Smooth and quiet. You can barely hear it. Close shave. The trimmer isn't all that great, but the floating head shaver is great in or out of the shower.
  705. Made well and robust so far; not worth the cost though. Will go back to buying 2-3 cheaper ones for cost of this. Blades are blades and they get dull. The head is very flexible and comfortable. First time i paid more than $50 for a norelco shaver.<br />Wont do it again.
  706. I am impressed with this shaver. I had been using a blade before this and the shave is a little bettter with that. However, it is also rougher on the face. After using this shaver for about three weeks I find it to be nearly as good as the blade.<br /><br />The battery seems to perform as claimed. I don't get 17 shaves per charge but I get 14-15. Recharge in about an hour.<br /><br />Cleaning is very easy. Just rinse under hot water and let it dry. There doesn't seem to be any build-up in the heads.

  712. This razor is not bad. I have only used the cheaper electric razors in the past, including the $50 Norelco triple head shavers and those $10-$20 Remington shavers. I have never been impressed with those as the screens wear out quickly leading to a lot of cuts and irritation. I have never used the most expensive electric shavers so I could not compare this product to those, however I have used this product for about 4 months and find it very satisfactory.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-This razor is water resistant. It can be used in the shower with soap or a gel or foam for lather. In a pinch you can use it with just water but having a gell or foam really makes for less irritation.<br />-You can use it dry and because of the battery it is cordless meaning you can use it in your car or on a bus or train or something.<br />-It is relatively quiet. It doesn't sound like you are tattooing your face each time you use it.<br />-Battery life is pretty good on this. I charge it probably once every two weeks or less depending on how much its used. Also it charges very fast. If the battery is low or dead you can give it a charge for a few mins that will get you through at least one shave.<br />-Super easy cleanup. 99% of the shaved hairs stay inside the well under the cutting heads and can be flushed away in seconds if shaving in the shower it cleans as you shave but rinse when you are done anyway.<br />-Blade life is very good.<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Minor irritation, however this is to be expected when shaving.<br />-Like all electrics it will never cut as close as a safety razor but it will get pretty damned close to it.<br />-Some spots like directly under the jaw bone it seems to have a lot of difficulty in cutting and the skin must be pulled tightly and the razor passed over several times. typically i use a gillete mach 3 to touch up any areas missed.<br />-In some spots if the skin is especially soft it will not cut the hair, no matter how many times you pass the cutting heads over. in those spots if needed you can whip out a safety razor and knock it out in about 2 seconds.<br />-Charging must be done on the base you cannot connect the cord directly ( assume this helps keep it water resistant)<br /><br />A few notes. Don't waste your money on the version with a cleaning kit. Totally unneccesary. You can rinse it off after each use and the blades have low friction coatings so nothign is sticking and the cleaning stuff is just a waste of money for a nifty but useless gadget. The carrying case works fine but will not hold the charging cord so shove the cord in a bag or something you won't need it often anyway.
  713. I have used Norelco shavers for many years, most have been good, but not great. That is until I purchased this one. Incredible shave, charge lasts quite awhile. The only problem is that you have to take the whole charging unit with you when you travel. highly recommend!

  732. I needed to replace a 10-year-old Norelco shaver.   742. I started using an electric razor about 15 years ago when I had decided that it was a more civilized way to shave. I had gone through three Remington Titanium MS3 2700 Washable foil razors. These units gave me a close shave and I was pretty much satisfied with them. Recently, I felt that it was time for an upgrade. I had seen the Norelco 1250x40 Senso Touch 3D Electric Razor and was impressed with the design. I recently purchased it from Amazon and have been pleased with the entire experience. The unit arrived in just a few days. I charged it up and proceeded to take my first shave. I must tell you that I am totally impressed with the experience. Norelcos are quiet to begin with but this unit is exceptional and the shave was superior to any electric that I have ever owned. I had also read that some people were dissatisfied with the trimmer; I am not. I think that it works very well. I also had no trouble with the blades getting near the hairs near my nose. I had read about the dry vs. wet shave discussion. I prefer shaving oil. I find it to be vastly superior to any type of liquid pre electric shave formulation or shave cream. I had read about shaving oil on the internet and decided to try it. I purchased Shave Secret and noticed an immediate improvement. I was not impressed with the price, though. I was paying good money for what seemed to be a minuscule bottle of baby oil. I tried some actual baby oil and found that to be too thick. I then tried a few drops of some Avon Skin So Soft Bath Oil that I had used as mosquito repellent. It was absolutely fantastic. Just make sure to keep your face wet. Its all that I will ever use. The combination of the Norelco Senso Touch and the Skin So Soft make shaving an absolutely enjoyable experience. As far as saving me time shaving, I find just the opposite. I enjoy it so much that I have added a few minutes each day. Finally, the shaver is expensive but I think that it is worth every penny that I paid for it.

  750. I probably should have wrote this review a few months ago but I have some weird morale conflicts with writing negative reviews. After contemplating, I decide to just go ahead and write a quick description of my experience.<br /><br />First off, I want to state that I usually buy 1 to 3 products from Amazon Prime a week. Every product I have purchased has been exactly what I expected and the review systems has always lead me to making intelligent and safe purchases. When I began looking for a new (and also my first) electric shaver, I spent several weeks researching and comparing products and the norelco just seemed to be the right buy. I consulted with my hairy men friends and business associates and they told me that they have used multiple brands in the past but Norelco was always the champion in competitions.<br /><br />Well, I went ahead and purchased this little guy and off the bat I was very satisfied. I received the well packaged box, opened it up, ran to my home restroom, and released myself of my facial furriness. I have to admit, the shave was very nice and clean. My girlfriend even complemented me since this was her first time ever seeing my face completely shaved. I then waited about 2 weeks and went to town again. The shave was equally as impressive and easy as the first shave. I was actually so impressed, I went back onto amazon and purchased the Philips Norelco QT4070 Vacuum Beard, Stubble and Mustache Trimmer Pro. After receiving my new shaver, I retired my original and more expensive shaver for emergency's only.<br /><br />I unplugged my SensoTouch and stored it safely into my bottom drawer for hibernation. Several months later, it was time for wedding season. I pulled out my SensoTouch the night prior, plugged it in, and went to sleep. The following morning I went into the restroom to get my shave started and realized, my beautiful animations informing me that my razor was ready for action, was actually missing in action. No information informationshowing, no blinking lights, nothing. I tried unplugging and plugging it back in (This usually works with my windows laptop), but nothing. I tried adjusting the arrangement of the razor with the charging dock, but nothing.<br /><br />I decide to just use the other cheaper razor and just get a close shave instead of the clean shave. I wasn't a happy camper and I was more than frustrated. I had to get going so I decided to call norelco on the way to the wedding and try to get some instructions or help. Customer Service told me that my razor that I literally used twice, was now out of warranty and they couldn't assist me. I was astonished and they would provide me with absolutely no help. I called in the next day and got the exact same response.<br /><br />All in all, for nearly $200 dollars, I received 2 $100 shaves. I don't blame Amazon for this issue but I must say, I feel really cheated by Philips. I haven't bought a replacement for the Senso but I will definitely not be investing in another $200 dollar Phillips product in the future. Please be weary of the warranty and be sure to frequently test your product before you warranty expires or you will be in the same predicament that I'm in.

  758. So disappointed in this razor's durability. This was purchased as a Christmas gift 2012. For the price thought this would be a durable razor to last for a few years. Maybe used 75 times and was cleaned after using. As a few other longer term users are reporting this one is now toast. Wish I could say it was just the blades dulling out and not being able to find replacement blades. In our case, the razor overheated while charging and blew up. This razor was treated with care and didn't travel. A high end razor should last longer than a cheaper one and replacement blades should not be obsolete or overpriced while they are still selling the product.<br />UPDATE - Since I left a negative review I wanted to update. After realizing we had a two year warranty I contacted Phillips for a replacement. After some negotiation they did send us a replacement razor. Body only no new charger or blades which is all we needed. Replacement came quickly and included a postage paid label to send the damaged unit back. It has lasted almost a year now. So based on that I am upgrading my review from a 1 star to 3 stars. The working razor itself is a 5 but the durability of the first one was poor. I have to give their CS a 5 also.

  771. I tried other electric shavers years ago, but didn't like them. I have been using Norelco shavers for the past 25 years now and they just keep getting better. I do have two gripes about this razor though:<br />1) You have to put the razor on its charging stand in order to charge it. It would have been nice to be able to plug the charging cord directly into the razor. It would have given the razor more portability. Instead you have to lug the razor, which is larger than I expected, plus the cord, and the stand with you when you travel.<br />2) The razor itself is larger than I expected. My last Norelco shaver, which was very adequate, took up a lot less space in my suitcase.<br />My wishlist for Norelco - A smaller version of this razor which does not require a charging stand.

  783. I just bought the 1255x shaver and decided to put up a review on it as well as this model, as this is the smae shaver minus the extra head and silver exterior.<br /><br />This shaver is probably the best shaver (shaving-wise) i have had in all 10 years i am shaving so far!<br />It has a solid build that when dropped, does not break like my old shaver.<br />It is waterproof (a must for anyone who hasn't yet tried shaving underwater). It is particularly good for me as i have delicate skin and begin to get all sorts of spots on my face soon after i shave. I got this shaver at costco for $115 after mail-in-rebate which is a pretty sweet deal considering that the shaver itself is worth more than that and it comes with a extra shaving head replacement! I love the moving heads that help catch all the hairs on your chin, neck and under the chin.<br /><br />The only problem i have with this shaver is that it is much bulkier than my last shaver and it does dispense shaving cream. The new one requires you to charge it using the charging stand, you can't just plug the charging cord into the bottom of the shaver like the old one. The new one doesn't feel as good in my hand when shaving, a personal preference or course. Pros: Its quieter (but the old one was already very quiet). That's about it.

  799. I purchased this razor to replace my old, worn out Philips Norelco razor of over 6+ years. Since I have had a great experience in the past, I was eager to continue with the Philips brand. I am very pleased with this razor thus far (over 30+ shave's). It cuts clean, and close, and doesn't seem to &#34;pull&#34; the hair as much as my old razor did. I find that the razor head is a bit larger than the previous models, as well as the cutting surface on the head being a bit father inside, leaving a small gap of plastic on the outside. This makes it harder to reach tight corners of my face (such as directly underneath the nose to cut all the hairs of my mustache). A little persistence helps me get these hard to reach areas. I am very pleased, and although I cannot speak of the durability quite yet, I believe and hold faith that this razor will continue to give me the convenient, close shave I have been used to for years.

  823. Prior to this one, I had the Norelco Cool Skin 7775X; if you don't recognize that particular model it's because it's probably almost 10 years old. It was a good shaver, but I FINALLY couldn't find any more shave lotion to go with it. So it was time to upgrade. Norelco had been good to me so I decided to give it another go and found this shaver.<br /><br />I used it to shave my entire head and face with no soap, no lotion, no nothing and it was the most smooth shaving experience I'd ever had. Zero irritation, zero redness, no razor burn. And I didn't even have to use any shaving lotion! If I had tried to do that with my old 7775X, it would have felt like each individual hair was being plucked from my head with a pair of tweezers. The experience was only bearable with lotion; not the case with this shaver! My face and head are nice and smooth and it was extremely convenient not having to lotion-up my whole head and rinse the shaver heads every 10 seconds. It even gently cut my thick beard hairs and I didn't even have to use the trimmer attachment first! And it had more than plenty enough battery to do my entire head, face and neck and still had power left.<br /><br />I only shave once every 2 weeks, because I hate doing it. It's time consuming, uncomfortable, messy and annoying. This was honestly the best shave I've ever had. And I did it in record time too. So if you're like me, and you want a quick, comfortable shave without the mess... look no farther. This is your shaver. Expensive? Yes. Worth every penny? Also yes! GET THIS! You won't regret it.

  826. Giving a 1-star review because:<br /><br />1. Having purchased this product just over a year ago, the &#34;replace head&#34; light is flashing, which is fine, but the problem is that the original head is no longer available and have been replaced by &#34;RQ12+&#34;. If you check out the review comments for those heads, there are a lot of negative comments. If Philips made the original head available for purchase too (at a reasonable price), then fair enough. But one year after purchasing this product I do expect to be able to purchase a replacement head with the same design as the original head. Actually I would hope to be able to still buy it *several* years after purchase. The product information says that the redesigned head is superior but, based on the reviews, I don't think so, so I would buy the original if I could, but I cannot. No consumer choice = very bad. Oh wait, I found the original heads on Amazon. Nearly two hundred dollars.<br /><br />2. When I first bought this shaver there were so many different variants (with/without cleaning, and many other options), that it was pretty confusing. NOW, it seems that Philips Marketing have nothing better to do than to come up with new names for a product that they already shipped. Series 8000 now, apparently. Just as if it wasn't already confusing enough.<br /><br />3. Going back to the head thing, this product, if you buy it new on Amazon, shows that the heads are the original ones. So what, the original head design *is* available and still in production, but only if you buy another brand new shaver??!!<br /><br />BTW, the actual product worked well so far, but his one-star review is well-deserved because of the above.
